and G-Class (refer Table 1) .  RAWL 02 MK III is  s u p p l i e d  i n  f o u r  c o n f i g u r a t i o n s  a s  l i s t e d

FFERENCES BETWEEN SYSTEMS SUPPLIED FOR SYSTEM 1, 4 AND SYSTEM 2, 3, 5 
7. (a) RAWL02 Mk -III supplied with certain chan ges operates on either 50 Hz or     
60 Hz supply. System 1, 4 (INS Mysore, ND(MB) operates on 50 Hz and System 
2, 3, 5 (INS Betwa, INS Beas, INS Vira at) operates on 60 Hz  (refer Table 3 ). 
The succeeding paragraphs 7(b) to 10 describe the changes required between 
Systems 1, 4 and 2, 3, 5.   
(b) The below deck equipment consisting of Transmitter Cabinet, Receiver Cabinet, 
Video Extr

actor and Cooling Cabinet wo rk on 440 V, 3 Phase supply whose 
frequency can be 50 Hz or 60 Hz.  
(c) The above deck equipment namely the St abilised antenna and Hydraulic Power 
Unit are modified for working with 380 V, 3 Phase, 50 Hz supply or 440 V,  
3 Phase, 60 Hz supply.

RAWL 02 Mk III - G-Class / Preface                                                                                                                   -A5-  (d) The changes to HPU are only for power supply voltage and not for frequency; 
hence there is no Part No. change.  Th e requisite changes in the input power 
supply connections in the HPU are indi cated in the OEM supplied handbook of 
HPU (Ordering No. : 9102 008 690 58). 
(e) The changes to the Stabilised antenna ar e carried out in fact ory for keepi

ng the 
same antenna rotation rate of 7.5/15 rpm for 50 Hz or 60 Hz.  Changes are the 
different drive motor and the gearbox in B-drive.  Hence the part numbers of 
these devices are different. 
(f) The change in power supply frequenc y has also necessitated an embedded 
program change in Receiver cabinet, in two MPU boards.  Hence part numbers 
of MPU boards and associated part numbers have been changed.  
(g) The change of part numbers however does not necessitate any change in 
technical description, mai

ntenance or repa ir of the concerned parts as the items 
are form and functional replaceable.  The technical manual references have to be 
read in conjunction with the follo wing cross-reference  Table 3 .  
(h) L-Synth Part No. 9556 734 162XX - The L-Synth part number 9556 734 080XX 
has been changed by OEM to 9556 734 162XX, however the reference 
mentioned in handbooks is 9556 734 080XX.  Hence for all references in the 
technical manuals for L-Synth Part No. 9556 734 080XX read changed part no. 
9556 73

4 162XX.  The part number 9556 734 060XX is changed to  
3522 500 57617.  The L-Synth may be any one of the part numbers.

DIFFERENCES BETWEEN SYSTEMS SUPPLIED FOR SHIPS 1-5 AND P15A  
11. (a) RAWL 02 Mk III system supplied to P15A  class of ships differs from systems 
supplied to ships 1-5 due to addition of  backup transmitt

er (Refer Fig. 2). The 
introduction of backup transmitter reduces the life cycle costs of the TWT and 
increasing the radar system availabilit y. The radar with certain changes is 
modified for operation with backup transmitter. The succeeding paragraphs 11
(b) to 46 describes the differences from system 1-5 to P15A.  
(b) An RF Coupler splits the RF input signal and supplies to TWT and BTC.  This 
requires modification in the transmitter cabinet.  LNTAs in the transmitter 
cabinet are placed in the BTC.

STC signals are fed to the BTC from the 
receiver.  The RF circuit in the tr ansmitter is modified (refer Fig. 4 ).

RAWL 02 Mk III - G-Class / Preface                                                                                                                   -A7-  (c) Control of the BTC is done either from lo cal control panel of the transmitter or 
by remote.  This requires addition of control switches and PCB CTRLLW on the 
LCP-PR-UN of transmitter.  The status and tellbacks from BTC are sent to 
transmitter cabinet and receiver cabinet.  LCP-PR-UN is modified (refer  
Fig. 5 ). 
12. The waveguide assembly is com

pletely modified to connect transmitted signal either 
from TWT or BTC (refer Fig. 7 ). 
13. The Video extractor is replaced by state of the art VEXTMS.  
14. Hence changes in part numbers between systems supplied for 1-5 and P15A (refer 
Tables 4 to 10 below.

Changes in Transmitter Cabinet 
17. RF IN is split by a co-coupl er U3 (3522 500 23729) and sent to TWT and BTC.  Refer 
functional diagram given in Fig. 4 below : 
 
 
FIG. 4 
Functional Diagram RF Circuit U3

RAWL 02 Mk III - G-Class / Preface                                                                                                                   -A11-  18. The switches TWT Pre-heat, TWT, BTC ar e added on the local control panel for 
selecting TWT or BTC or start heating of the BTC.  The figur e below indicates the additional 
switches. 
19. Control of the BTC and status of BT C is reported to LW08 by CTRLLW -  
1121 000 870 97 (9556 831 095XX).  CTRLLW is moun ted in the local control panel unit of 
t

ransmitter cabinet along with a backplan e - 1121 000 871 94 (9198 720 481XX).  CTRLLW 
receives all control signals from  LCP or remote and gives the go ahead for transmission either to 
the BTC or TWT. 
20. Selection of the transmitting power source fo r the antenna - TWT or BTC is done by 
means of manual operation in the waveguide switch.  RF power can also be sent to the RF load 
(for test or maintenance purposes). 
21. LCP-PR-UN switches OFF/STNDBY/RDY/TR MT are used for BTC and TWT. 
22. Waveguide sw

itch position has to be cha nged manually from ANT to load, BTC to 
TWT. 
23. Transmission has to be stopped before changing over the waveguide switch position. 
24. For test and maintenance purpose, TWT can be connected to RF load when BTC is 
connected to antenna and vice versa. 
25. Before switching on the waveguide switch from BTC to TWT operation, the TWT is 
pre-heated. 
26. Control of the BTC and status of BTC is reported to LW08 by CTRLLW  
(9556 831 095XX).  CTRLLW is mount ed in the local control

pane l unit of transmitter cabinet 
along with a backplane (9198 720 481XX).  
 
FIG. 5

(a) Interfaces BTC with transmitter and receiver of RAWL02 Mk III 
(b) Controls BTC 
(c) Receives status from BTC and reports to transmitter and receiver

Signal Function

coolin

g.

(battle).

deck to enable transmission.

DIFFERENCES BETWEEN S

YSTEMS SUPPLIED FOR G-CLASS AND P15A 
47. RAWL02 Mk III system supplied for G-class differs from systems supplied for P15A 
due to change of stabilized antenna to unstabilized antenna. The radar with certain changes can 
be modified for operation for unstabilized syst em.  Configuration of RAWL 02 Mk III for 
unstabilized system is given in Fig. 8 .  The succ eeding paragraphs describe the differences from 
P15A to G-Class. 
48. The antenna is completely modified from stabilized to unstabilized system.  The

stabilized platform is removed and modifications are implemented in antenna to prevent signal 
and possible detection/track loss.  
49. The Hydraulic Power Unit is completely removed.  Due to the removal of HPU, control 
of B-drive antenna is incorporated in the PSD unit of transmitter cabinet .  Additional connectors 
CD2, CD3 introduced in PSD unit for the same.  A 3-ph transformer is introduced in the PSD 
unit to convert 440 V, 3 ph to 115 V, 3 ph to pr ovide supply for oil heat ing in the B-drive. 
5

removed in the receiver.  This requires PCBs  removal and wiring modi fications in ACU, card

II.LITERATURE REVIEWbased PK/PDsimulator primarilyaimed at biomedical researchers with minimal experience in PK/PD. Fig.1.A4S:PK/PDsimulator work flowchart Sandeep Sanga et. al [5] worked on a computer simulation to predict drug pharmacokinetics and effect in vascularized tumors .This paper explores the pharmacokinetics and effects of cisplatin and doxorubicin in vascularized tumors through 2D computer simulations . The study supports the idea that simulation -based modeling is vital in understanding the pharmacological behavior , as stated in the work of Sruthi V.B. [6] who demonstrated that simulation -based training also significantly improves applied medical skillsets like CPR .The authors take vascular and morphological heterogeneity into account and also cellular and lesion -level PK determinants like cell density P-glycoprotein (Pgp) efflux . A multi - compartmental PK/ PD model was constructed from experimental data and a 2-hour bolus administration and sub

secuently a 18-hour drug washout was simulated . The authors observed that vascular architecture , nutrient gradients , and cellular density played important roles in tumor penetration . The model incorporates differential equations to simulate drug transport , cellular uptake , and tumor response . The tumor microenvironment is modelled using steady - state diffusion equations which determine distribution of nutrients and oxygen . PD is model ed using a Hill-type function , linking drug exposure to cell inhibition . Massimiliano Germani , et.al, [3] proposed A4S, a user-frien

dly graphical tool for pharmacokinetic and pharmacody namic (PK/ PD) simulation , in which their view is that one of the shortcomings in biomedical research is the lack of a user- friendly tool which enables “non-professionals ” to utilize PK/ PD models without having toacquire technica l expertise and know-how in sophisticated mathematical concepts andexpert software . Kapoor et al. [4] similarly emphasized that user education and simplified guidelines are key factors influencing successful therapeutic outcomes in emergency care environments . Some software limitations also play an important role: The cost of commercial software prevent s wide-range distribution of it. Most biomedical software in research are proprietary software ’ that have restricted access to specific organizations or individuals , usually behind a paywall barrier . ‘

CLA 128,and tumor sizewasmeasured atvarious time points toassess drug efficacy .Itfollows atwo-compartmental model ,acentral compartment (blood plasma )andaperipheral compartment (the tissue ).Forclearance ,twomethods were employed ,linear clearance (regular breakdown process inside lysosomes )and non-linear clearance (thedecomposition ofthedrug inside the tumor cells).Tumor growth wasmodelled using azero-order growth model .EffectsofMCLA -128 isoftwo aspects : Inhibition oftumor growth rateandincrease intumor death rate. n the applications of therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM ) are discussed to enhance drug therapy through monitoring drug plasma concentrations and adjusting dosing based on pharmacokinetics . TDM aims to optimize therapeutic effect as well as to reduce side effects and address issues of drug interaction and drug poisoning . In this context , Babu and Pavithran [13] also argue that therapeutic drug monitoring based on pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic data is becoming essential to move beyond fixed -dose paradigms toward individualized pharmacotherapy .The work introduces variables like genetics , compliance with the drug, and drug interaction that influence drug metabolism and action . Although the data used here are informative , additional investigation is required in order to come up with extra information regarding cumulative effects of the use of TDM in disparate patient populations and clinics .7 Geremew DT,Kasahun AEet.al,[14]came forward with a study demonstrating thatsolid ,semi -solid ,andliquid were the most prevailing dosage forms with oral,rectal ,andnasal administration respectively ,bytraditional healers .Thepractice oftracking thestatus oftheformulations waspoor,which is consistent tothefacts stated byKrahenb uhl-Melcher ,A., Schlienger [1].Traditional healers hasafavourable attitude towards therequirement fordifferent dosage forms androute of administration .Thestakeholders must offer consistent training and experience sharingbetween traditional healers and p

III.METHODOLOGY A.Dataset Generation Due tounavailability ofrequired medical data,wehave synthetically generated thedata forthepurpose oftraining theneural network model .The sample dataset comprises of values forheight ,weight (forBMI calculation ),blood pressure (both diastolic andsystolic ),age,gender andtemperature .For gender ,binary hasbeen used as0forfemale and1formale , togenerate thedataset .Thepharmacokinetic equation fororal drug dosing isgiven as(1), C=D·F·Ka Vd(Ka−Ke)·(e−Ke·t−e−Ka·t) (1) where ,D=dose,Vd=volume ofdistribution ,Ke=elimina - tionrateconstant ,Ka=absorption rateconstant ,F=fraction absorbed (bioavailability ),t=duration ofinfusion ,C=plasma concentration ofthedrug. Now,since weknow using Arrhenius equation (2), K=A·e−Ea RT (2) where ,K=rateconstant ,T=temperature ;Ea=Activation energy ;R=Universal Gas constant ,A=Arrhenius constant Wecanassume anexponential relation between thedrug dosing andbody temperature using proportionality .Thefactors have been calculated using arbitrary weights forthegiven parameter (3), factor =(0.45·age)+(0.2·gender )+(0.1·temperature ) +(0.15·BMI )+(0.1·SysBP )(3) Thecontribution oftheweights might vary forarealtime dataset . Sample drug dose hasbeen generated using theequation (4). dose =base dose·efactor(4) Thetotal number of1000 data points hasbeen generated and used inthedataset .The codes forthefinal dataset generation hasbeen attached inthesection Source code . IV.PRECISE DOSE DESIGN The goal istodevelop aninteractive software that could simulate real-world medical emergency situations andenable practitioners tocalibrate drug dosages based upon several patient -specific parameters . Thesoftwareisprimarily divided intotwoparts :Theback -end model thatperforms thedrug dosage prediction andinterfac e, which isaimed tobefully interactive inorder togive theuser a realistic experience ofperforming under thestress during a medical emergency . PreciseDose isbuilt onPython 3.10.The libraries used inthesoftware aregiveninTable1. Table1.Librariesusedandtheirpurpose A.System Architecture Thearchitecture ofPreciseDose isstructured insuch away thatintegration between thesimulation environment ,prediction model ,and the user interface is smooth during communication between thementioned .Thesystem isdivided into sub-modules : • Patients ’JSON filerepository • Drugs ’JSON filerepository • ONNX dosage prediction model • Custom LinkedList andGraph data-structures • RealtimeSTT (Speech -To-Text)using PyTorch • Llama 3.2text-based feature extraction • Tkinter Interface 1) Flat-filedata repositories :JSON filesareflexible interms ofstructure and versatility .Patients ’JSON files consist information likedefault parameters ,vitals ,history ,etc.while drugs ’files JSON contain drug specific parameters likenormal doselevels ,bioavailability ,clearance rateandabsorption time. 2) ONNX Integration :Python hasexcellent support forOpen Neural Network Exchange (ON

NX )through ORT (ONNX RunTime ).This allows forquick loading andinfer ence of models stored inthe.onnx format directly .One more reason why wedecided tointegrate ONNX isdue toitscross - framework compatibility ,allowing ustoinitially develop and train themodelusing MATLAB andthen deploy itusing Python .3)Speech -To-Text using PyTorch :RealtimeSTT listens to themicrophone andtranscribes voice intotext.Itisbased upon 2dependency models :aV AD (V oice Activity Detection )filter andaSpeech Recognition Model . •SileroV AD foraccurate verification ofvoice activity . •Faster Whisper forGPU -accelerated transcrip tion. 4)Text feature extraction using Llama 3.2:Wehave in- corporated Llama 3.2,alightweight (3Bparameter )Large Language Model inorder toserve basic language tasks such astoextract keypatient parameters from atranscript ,compare user’sprocedure with theexpected and provid e feedback. 5)Tkinter Interface :When thesoftware isrun,Tkinter is called forthecreation ofafull-screen window (1920x1080 resolution bydefault ). B.Hierarchical filesystem PreciseDose makes useofWindows ’hierarchical filesystem thatuses directories toorganize files intoatreestructure .Code andcontent aremanaged indifferent dedicated sub-directories andevery individual filepath istracked andeasily traceable . This tree structure (Fig.3)allows forefficient organization andretrieval offiles. Fig.3.Hierarchical filesystem C.Workflow Fig.4shows theworkflow ofthesoftware . Fig.4. Workflow ofthesoftware

PMID :37408583 ;PMCID :PMC 10319467 .VI.CONCLUSION This proposalaims toprovide calibrated drug dosage and hands ontraining fordrug dosing tothemedical practitioners . This hasbeen achieved bymaking auserfriendly interface anda drug dose calibrating model based onrealtime parameters such astemperature ,blood pressure etc.Feed-forward neural networks have been used,which isfurther integrated toPy

thon based application.Tomake itmore userconvenient ,aspeech to textmodel isintegrated totake voice inputs from theuser to simulate clinical conditions .Themodel hasachieved 99.19% accuracy ontestdatataken from synthetically generated dataset . Models mentioned intheliterature review focus more towards thecomplexitythan theuser-friendly approach ofthemodel . Herein ,theneural network hasbeen integrated tobeginner - friendly softwareandtherefore providing feasibility foritsusein hospital environment .Along with theuserfriendly approach and better accuracy using deep learning neural networks ,themodel alsoholds options totakeinrealtime datafrom theuserandstore itintopatient specific database .

(b) The below deck equipment consisting of Transmitter Cabinet, Receiver Cabinet, Video Extractor and Cooling Cabinet wo rk on 440 V, 3 Phase supply whose frequency can be 50 Hz or 60 Hz. (c) The above deck equipment namely the St abilised antenna and Hydraulic Power Unit are modified for working with 380 V, 3 Phase, 50 Hz supply or 440 V, 3 Phase, 60 Hz supply.

RAWL 02 Mk III - G-Class / Preface -A5- (d) The changes to HPU are only for power supply voltage and not for frequency; hence there is no Part No. change. Th e requisite changes in the input power supply connections in the HPU are indi cated in the OEM supplied handbook of HPU (Ordering No. : 9102 008 690 58). (e) The changes to the Stabilised antenna ar e carried out in fact ory for keeping the same antenna rotation rate of 7.5/15 rpm for 50 Hz or 60 Hz. Changes are the different drive motor and the gearbox in B-drive. Hence the part numbers of these devices are different. (f) The change in power supply frequenc y has also necessitated an embedded program change in Receiver cabinet, in two MPU boards. Hence part numbers of MPU boards and associated part numbers have been changed. (g) The change of part numbers however does not necessitate any change in technical description, maintenance or repa ir of the concerned parts as the items are form and functional replaceable. The technical manual references have to be read in conjunction with the follo wing cross-reference Table 3 . (h) L-Synth Part No. 9556 734 162XX - The L-Synth part number 9556 734 080XX has been changed by OEM to 9556 734 162XX, however the reference mentioned in handbooks is 9556 734 080XX. Hence for all references in the technical manuals for L-Synth Part No. 9556 734 080XX read changed part no. 9556 734 162XX. The part number 9556 734 060XX is changed to 3522 500 57617. (a) RAWL 02 Mk III system supplied to P15A class of ships differs from systems supplied to ships 1-5 due to addition of backup transmitter (Refer Fig. 2). The introduction of backup transmitter reduces the life cycle costs of the TWT and increasing the radar system availabilit y. The radar with certain changes is modified for operation with backup transmitter. The succeeding paragraphs 11 (b) to 46 describes the differences from system 1-5 to P15A. (b) An RF Coupler splits the RF input signal and supplies to TWT and BTC. This requires modification in the transmitter cabinet. LNTAs in the transmitter cabinet are placed in the BTC. STC signals
are fed to the BTC from the receiver. The RF circuit in the tr ansmitter is modified (refer Fig. 4 ).

LCP-PR-UN is modified (refer Fig. 5 ). 12. The waveguide assembly is completely modified to connect transmitted signal either from TWT or BTC (refer Fig. 7 ). 13. Subject to restrictive legend on title page Introduction to FFP 1-1 9501 817 913XX CHP 001 00 009501 916 007XX CHP 001 00 00CHAPTER 1 General Fault Finding Philosophy 1I N T R O D U C T I O N When the system (i.e. the collection of items forming the system) does not meet the requirements as mentioned in part 1, a fault has occurred. The purpose of fault finding is to isolate hardware faults down to Line Replaceable Unit (LRU) level as quickly as possible. The fault finding procedures are subject to the following assumptions: -t h e r e i s o n e f a u l t y L R U a t a t i m e , -t h e f a u l t i s c o n t i n u o u s l y p r e s e n t ( n o t i n t e r m i t t e n t ) , -t h e f a u l t i s n o t a w i r i n g f a u l t o r b a d c o n n e c t i o n , -p r i o r t o t h e o c c u r r e n c e o f t h e f a u l t t h e s y s t e m w a s f u n c t i o n i n g c o r r e c t l y , -f a u l t s a r e n o t m a s k e d . The following paragraphs describe the fault detection, fault localisation and post repair check possibilities. Note: It is possible that some items described in this document are not applicable to this system. 2F A U L T D E T E C T I O N A fault is detected when the system does not perform within the system's specifications. A fault can show itself in two ways: -t h r o u g h a n i n d i c a t i o n ( l a m p , L E D o r e r r o r r e p o r t ) g e n e r a t e d b y t h e h a r d w a r e a n d / o r s o f t w a r e of the system,

-t h r o u g h a p e r c e p t i b l e d e g r a d a t i o n o f t h e s y s t e m p e r f o r m a n c e ( e . g . m a l f u n c t i o n i n g o f d i s c r e t e s or displays). A fault can be detected: -a t a n y i t e m o f t h e s y s t e m , w h i c h i s n o r m a l l y c o n n e c t e d t o t h e s y s t e m , -a t a n y c o n t r o l p a n e l o f a n y i t e m w h i c h i s o p e r a t e d o r v i s i b l e d u r i n g o p e r a t i o n a l u s e , -w i t h a n y l o a d e d p r o g r a m , -w i t h o u t a p r o g a m b e i n g l o a d e d ( d u r i n g s w i t c h i n g o n o r o f f ) . 3F A U L T L O C A L I S A T I O N After the detection of the fault, the fault can be isolated with the aid of part 6 of the handbook. Part 6 comprises: -6 A : Service diagrams, -6 B ( 1 ) : F a u l t f i n d i n g p r o c e d u r e s a t s y s t e m l e v e l ,

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title page Introduction to FFP 1-2 9501 817 913XX CHP 001 00 00 9501 916 007XX CHP 001 00 00-6 B ( 2 ) : F a u l t f i n d i n g p r o c e d u r e s a t f u n c t i o n a l l e v e l , -6 B ( 3 ) : T e s t p a c k a g e m a n u a l . After the detection of a fault the maintainer should take no further action before consulting part 6B(1): Fault finding procedures at system level. In this category the fault is isolated down to functional level and reference is made to part 6B(2), where the fault is isolated to LRU level or reference is made to part 6A, service diagrams. Part 6B(3) contains a description of all test facilities available within the system delivery. Also the hardware which is tested by the various test facilities is outlined. After the isolation of a faulty LRU but before any removal, repair or adjustment activity is attempted, the maintainer must consult chapter 2, safety instructions, as well as the following documentation: -P a r t 5 T e s t a n d a d j u s t m e n t p r o c e d u r e s a n d i f n e c e s s a r y : -P a r t 4 M a i n t e n a n c e i n s t r u c t i o n s . During fault finding dangerous situations may occur which will be indicated by safety symbols. These safety symbols which are placed in the fault finding procedure are described in chapter 2. Fault finding procedures are in the form of flow charts. The symbols which are used as well as frequently used terms are described in c

hapter 3. Chapter 4 contains information about frequently used methods of isolating faulty LRUs. 4P O S T R E P A I R C H E C K After the isolation and the repair of the fault the maintainer may perform a post repair check using part 6B(3), test package manual. This part can be used to check that the system does meet the requirements set out in the handbook.

Safety Instructions 2-1 9501 921 113XX CHP 002 01 00 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageCHAPTER 2 Safety Instructions 1I N T R O D U C T I O N 1.1 General Maintenance can present danger if safety precautions are not observed. Whilst every precaution is taken when manufacturing the system to avoid danger to personnel, the human element can never be completely eliminated. This chapter gives an indication of the danger areas of the equipment, and instructions on how to avoid accidents or equipment damage when operating or maintaining the equipment. The following details are given: -t y p e o f d a n g e r , -c o n s e q u e n c e s o f t h e d a n g e r , i n t h e c a s e o f i n j u r y , -p r e c a u t i o n s t o a v o i d d a n g e r o r i n j u r y , -p o s s i b l e l o c a t i o n s o f d a n g e r , -i n d i c a t i o n s o f d a n g e r , -g e n e r a l p r e c a u t i o n s , -p r e c a u t i o n s t o a v o i d e q u i p m e n t d a m a g e . The likelihood of the physical injury depends, among other things, on the following factors: -t h e p r o f e s s i o n a l s k i l l o f o p e r a t i n g a n d m a i n t e n a n c e p e r s o n n e l , -t h e k n o w l e d g e o f t h e s e p e r s o n n e l c o n c e r n i n g p o s s i b l e r i s k s , -t h e d e g r e e o f c o n c e n t r a t i o n o f t h e s e p e r s o n n e l d u r i n g t h e i r w o r k , -t h e t y p e o f w o r k . Personnel operating, maintaining or repair

ing the equipment, and people located in the near vicinity of this equipment must be informed of possible risks. This advice in no way supersedes any instruction issued from a higher authority or contained in Departmental Standing Orders. 1.2 Safety Signs This paragraph illustrates and explains where necessary, all signs which are used to indicate danger or specific areas where special precautions must be taken.

Fig. 2-7 Safety Sign for Ultra Violet Radiation 2P E R S O N A L P R O T E C T I O N 2.1 General In spite of the many safety precautions taken, accidents can still occur. Utilising protective clothing and other facilities for personal protection which are available can minimise the chance of personal injury when working in dangerous situations. The chance of injury in potentially dangerous situations can be minimised by performing the task by two persons, of which one is leading. 2.2 Working in Dangerous Situations Personal injury can be avoided by the use of protective clothing, etc. when working in the following situations: -w h e n t h e r e i s r i s k o f i n j u r y t o t h e e y e s o r f a c e ( w e l d i n g , i m p l o s i o n o f C R T s , e t c . ) , -w h e n t h e r e i s a r i s k o f i n j u r y t o t h e e a r s ( e x p l o s i o n , h i g h n o i s e l e v e l s , e t c . ) , -w h e n t h e r e i s a r i s k o f i n j u r y t o t h e h a n d s ( h a n d l i n g c h e m i c a l s a n d o t h e r d a n g e r o u s substances), -w h e n t h e r e i s a r i s k o f i n j u r y t o t h e r e s p i r a t o r y s y s t e m ( b r e a t h i n g i n p o i s o n o u s f u m e s , g a s e s , etc.), -w h e n t h e r e i s a r i s k o f i n j u r y t o t h e h e a d ( f a l l i n g o b

j e c t s , e t c . ) , -w h e n t h e r e i s a r i s k o f f a l l i n g .3299535ULTRA-VIOLET THIS DEVICE CONTAINSCAUTION RADIATION A LAMP WHICH EMITS UV-RADIATION WHEN THE INTERLOCK IS SHORTED9501 921 113XX FIG 015 01 00

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageSafety Instructions 2-8 9501 921 113XX CHP 002 01 002.2.1 Eye/Face Protection Injury to the eyes alone (i.e. blinding) can be avoided by the use of safety goggles. A face mask offers more complete protection, for the eyes, private spectacles and the rest of the face, from flying glass, sparks, spattering chemicals, etc. 2.2.2 Ear Protection When working in areas with a high noise level (engine room, etc.) ear defenders or ear plugs may be worn to avoid damage to hearing. As a guide, the ears must be protected where the permanent noise level is higher than 80 dBs, or levels higher than 90 dBs will be experienced for short periods. 2.2.3 Hand Protection When handling chemicals, certain cleaning agents or adhesives, etc. it is advised to wear rubber gloves. When handling CRTs, etc., where there is a risk of flying glass due to implosion of the CRT, it is advised to wear leather gloves. 2.2.4 Respiratory System Protection When working with chemicals which give off poisonous gases, when cleaning up damaged radio-active components or other similar situations, it is advised to wear an adequate gas mask to avoid breathing in dangerous fumes. 2.2.5 Head Protection In situations where there is a risk of objects falling from above or bumping of the head due to low beams, etc., a suitable safety helmet should be worn. 2.2.6 Protection from Falling When working at great height, on radar antennas, etc., it is advi

sed to wear a safety harness with safety line securely attached. When working with ladders, ensure that the ladder cannot slip. WARNING: The use of protective clothing, etc. does not mean that normal safety precautions can be ignored. The best protection against personal injury is care and attention when working.

Safety Instructions 2-9 9501 921 113XX CHP 002 01 00 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title page3E L E C T R I C I T Y 3.1 General In spite of the fact that the equipment has been provided with safety provisions, voltages in excess of 30 volts RMS or 50 VDC can be dangerous under certain circumstances, and higher voltage values can be fatal. It is emphatically recommended to strictly observe the following instructions: -o p e r a t i o n a n d m a i n t e n a n c e o f t h e s y s t e m m u s t o n l y b e c a r r i e d o u t b y f u l l y q u a l i f i e d p e r s o n n e l , -w h e n e v e r p o s s i b l e m a i n t e n a n c e a c t i v i t i e s m u s t b e p e r f o r m e d w i t h t h e e q u i p m e n t f u l l y switched off ( no voltages present). To bring the equipment to a switched off state and to ensure that it remains so, the following precautions must be taken: 3.1.1 Switching Off To ensure complete safety, all supply voltages to the equipment to be maintained must be switched off including those for anti-condensation heating. 3.1.2 Protection Against Accidental Switch On To prevent the equipment accidentally being switched on while maintenance is in progress the following precautions should be taken: -l o c k t h e s w i t c h e s o r r e m o v e t h e s w i t c h l e v e r ( i f p o s s i b l e ) , -r e m o v e t h e r e l e v a n t s u p p l y f u s e s a n d s t o r e t h e m i n a s a f e p l a c e , -p l a c e a w a r n i

n g n o t i c e w i t h t h e f o l l o w i n g t e x t c l o s e t o t h e s w i t c h o f f a r e a : 3.1.3 Additional Safety Measures -C h e c k t h a t n o v o l t a g e i s p r e s e n t o n a l l i n c o m i n g w i r i n g u s i n g a n a p p l i c a b l e v o l t m e t e r . -D i s c h a r g e a l l c a p a c i t o r s , e t c . t o e a r t h u s i n g a p r o p e r l y e a r t h e d d i s c h a r g e r o d . -D o n o t o v e r r i d e o r s h o r t c i r c u i t s a f e t y i n t e r l o c k s o n d o o r s , p a n e l s o r d r a w e r s . -W h e n p e r f o r m i n g a t w o m a n j o b , o n e m u s t a l w a y s b e i n c h a r g e .WARNING Do not switch on Maintenance in progress Location ....................... Removal of this warning notice is only permitted by ............

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageSafety Instructions 2-10 9501 921 113XX CHP 002 01 003.2 Working with Voltage Switched On It is stressed that where possible no voltages must be present when performing maintenance; where this is not possible e.g. when performing tests or making electrical adjustments, the following additional precautions must be taken: -b e f o r e b e g i n n i n g t h e t a s k , e n s u r e t h e w h e r e a b o u t s o f t h e m a i n s u p p l y s w i t c h ( e s ) i s k n o w n , -a l w a y s w o r k w i t h a s e c o n d m a n ( s a f e t y m a n ) , -r e m o v e a l l j e w e l l e r y ( r i n g s , w a t c h e s , m e d a l l i o n s , e t c . ) w h i c h c a n c o m e i n t o c o n t a c t w i t h l i v e components. Tuck tie into shirt, -a l w a y s w o r k w i t h o n e h a n d i n p o c k e t . U n d e r no circumstances use the free hand to grasp the chassis (earth): this can result in electric shock across the heart, -d o n o t s w i t c h o n m o r e v o l t a g e s o r p a r t s o f t h e e q u i p m e n t t h a n a r e a b s o l u t e l y n e c e s s a r y . 3.2.1 Additional Precautions to Avoid Damage to Equipment Not only damage to the person can occur when voltage is present, but also damage to the equipment if the following general rules are not observed: -d o n o t e x c h a n g e c o m p o n e n t s w i t h v o l t a g e s w i t c h e d o n . T h e e x t r e m e c h a n g e i n v o l t a g e

c a n b e very damaging to some components, -d o n o t t r y t o d i s c h a r g e c a p a c i t o r s , e t c . t o e a r t h w i t h v o l t a g e p r e s e n t , -d o n o t d r o p m e t a l l i c o b j e c t s i n t o t h e e q u i p m e n t w i t h v o l t a g e s w i t c h e d o n . D o n o t l e a v e f o r e i g n objects such as nuts, bolts, lengths of wire, etc. behind in the equipment. 3.3 Tools Tools must always be of the insulated type. All electric tools must be of the double insulated type, if possible. Otherwise check always if the earth-connection of the tool concerned is correct before starting the job. 3.4 Extinguishing Fires When a fire starts in a cabinet of the installation, the cabinet must be switched off immediately. The fire must be isolated and extinguished by means of a carbon dioxide extinguisher. It is better not to fight a fire in a cabinet with a powder extinguisher or water, since electronic circuits and wiring will become severely damaged. To shut off oxygen, the area must be closed off as quick as possible. 3.5 Personal Injury Injuries caused by electricity are mostly shocks and burns. It is recommended to consult a doctor in all cases.

Safety Instructions 2-11 9501 921 113XX CHP 002 01 00 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title page4W O R K I N G I N C O N F I N E D S P A C E S When working in confined spaces (such as radomes) fresh air can enter only by the small access hatch. Due to the lack of fresh air, maintainers may suffer some discomfort when working in the radome for long periods. Forced ventilation of the radome should be provided if men are to remain continuously in the radome for more than two hours. Ventilation may be provided by placing an electric fan close to the access hatch, or by ducting air into the radome via a flexible pipe from a vacuum cleaner or the ventilation system. 5A N T E N N A M O V E M E N T Unexpected movement of an antenna may cause considerable injuries to personnel nearby. Injuries may result not only from direct contact with the antenna, but also from a subsequent fall from the antenna mounting platform. Therefore whenever work is to be carried out in the vicinity of a moving antenna, the man aloft switch/maintenance switch for that system must be set to SAFE. See also paragraph 3.1.2. 6V A C U U M T U B E S To avoid personal injury when handling vacuum tubes (implosion danger) the following general safety precautions must be strictly observed. -O n l y s t o r e v a c u u m t u b e s i n t h e i r o r i g i n a l p a c k a g i n g . -A l w a y s w e a r p r o t e c t i v e c l o t h i n g ( i . e . l e a t h e r g l o v e s , a p r o n a

n d f a c e m a s k ) w h e n h a n d l i n g vacuum tubes. -N e v e r l i f t v a c u u m t u b e s b y t h e n e c k o r a m e c h a n i c a l l y s e n s i t i v e p a r t . -A l w a y s d i s c h a r g e a u s e d v a c u u m t u b e a c o u p l e o f t i m e s , i f a h i g h v o l t a g e w a s c o n n e c t e d . -P l a c e a v a c u u m t u b e o n a s o f t s u r f a c e . -C R T s s h a l l b e p l a c e d w i t h t h e s c r e e n f a c i n g d o w n ( w h e r e p o s s i b l e ) . -U s e e m p t y p a c k a g i n g f o r t r a n s p o r t o f t h e e x c h a n g e d t u b e t o a d i s p o s a l p l a c e . 7R A D I O A C T I V E S U B S T A N C E S 7.1 Components Producing Ionising Radiation Ionising radiation is either produced by radioactive substances or, artificially by high-voltage vacuum tubes in operation (X-ray radiation). -R a d i o a c t i v e s u b s t a n c e s c o n t i n u o u s l y p r o d u c e r a d i a t i o n , w h i c h d e c r e a s e s i n t h e c o u r s e o f t i m e . This radiation may be injurious to health, requiring radioactive components to be handled with care. Examples are: -T R - c e l l s , -s p a r k g a p s ( s o m e t y p e s ) . -H i g h - v o l t a g e v a c u u m t u b e s e x a m p l e s a r e : -T r a v e l l i n g W a v e T u b e s , -S t a b i l i s a t i o n T u b e s .

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageSafety Instructions 2-12 9501 921 113XX CHP 002 01 00Under normal conditions, where the components are properly mounted in the unit, and the front plates and doors are fitted, the radiation is less than 0.1 mRem/h at a distance of 10 cm from unit. 7.2 Danger of Ionising Radiation Ionising rays may damage biological tissues and cells, the degree of damage depending on the kind of radiation and the energy level. Human organs which generate new cells, such as the spleen, the sexual organs and bone marrow, are very sensitive to these rays. Ionising radiation is not perceptible to the senses and the consequences are not immediately noticeable. Thus it is possible to receive a harmful dose of radiation whose effect will only be noticeable after a longer term. To avoid this, the dose of radiation a person is permitted to receive during a certain period of time is limited. At this moment the limit is 2 mS/year (0.2 Rem/year), averaging 1 µS/hour (0.1 mRem/hour) for 2000 working hours per year. In addition to the above risks, radioactive substances also include danger of contamination. This kind of danger occurs in those cases where the housing is absent or damaged, allowing the radioactive matter to become dispersed to cause internal or external contamination. In the latter case the radioactive substance may be carried in the clothing or on the skin for a longer period of time, exposing the body incessantly

to radiation. Internal contamination may even occur through normal breathing, if a radioactive gas is involved. Radioactive matter or liquid may cause contamination via the mouth or minor injuries. Internal contamination in particular is dangerous since the body is no longer protected by the skin. For these and other reasons, it is necessary to handle components containing radioactive substances with the utmost care to avoid breakage of the housing. 7.3 Disposal of Damaged Radioactive Components When the housing of a radioactive component is undamaged, the radiation risk has a limited character. If, on the other hand, the housing has somehow been damaged, the radiation risk is considerably higher. It is recommended, therefore, to carry a dosimeter which registers the total dose of radiation received. When a radioactive element has been damaged, the following measures must be observed: -c l e a r t h e a r e a o f p e r s o n n e l a n d s w i t c h o f f a n y i n l e t a n d e x h a u s t v e n t i l a t i o n t o t h e c o m p a r t m e n t , -p u t o n r u b b e r g l o v e s a n d , w i t h t h e u s e o f t w e e z e r s , p l a c e a l l p a r t s o f t h e b r o k e n / d a m a g e d component into an airtight container, -u s i n g a d h e s i v e t a p e , p i c k u p a l l t h e s m a l l p a r t i c l e s a n d p l a c e t h e a d h e s i v e t a p e , w i t h p a r t i c l e s attached, in the container, -d r a g a d a m p c l o t h o v e r t h e a r e a t o c o l

l e c t a n y d u s t , f o l d i n g t h e c l o t h i n w a r d s , a s n e c e s s a r y , until the cloth is too small to fold. Place the contaminated cloth in the container, -p l a c e a n y t o o l s u s e d f o r t h e r e m o v a l o f t h e c o n t a m i n a t e d c o m p o n e n t i n t o a s e p a r a t e c o n t a i n e r for decontamination, -r e m o v e g l o v e s w i t h o u t t o u c h i n g t h e o u t s i d e o f t h e g l o v e s a n d d r o p t h e m i n t o t h e c o n t a i n e r w i t h the broken parts, -s e a l t h e c o n t a i n e r s w i t h a d h e s i v e t a p e a n d L a b e l ‘ R a d i o a c t i v e M a t e r i a l ’ , -m o n i t o r t h e a r e a o f t h e a c c i d e n t w i t h a g e i g e r c o u n t e r , i n c l u d i n g a n y p e r s o n n e l a s s i s t i n g ,

Safety Instructions 2-13 9501 921 113XX CHP 002 01 00 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title page-w h e n t h e a r e a i s f r e e f r o m c o n t a m i n a t i o n , w a s h h a n d s t h o r o u g h l y w i t h s o a p a n d w a t e r , -i f a n y i n j u r y h a s o c c u r r e d d u r i n g t h e o p e r a t i o n , e n c o u r a g e b l e e d i n g f r o m a n y c u t s o r a b r a s i o n s and obtain qualified medical advice as soon as possible. On no account are personnel to eat, drink or smoke while disposing of broken or damaged radio- active components. Radioactive materials may only be transported in accordance with official directions. 7.4 Safety Sign Components, containing radioactive substances, are marked with the danger symbol according to Fig. 2-2 (without the text part). 7.5 Dosimeters 7.5.1 General It is recommended to use dosimeters for the measurement of the dose of ionising radiation received. This applies in particular to the following personnel: -t e c h n i c i a n s p e r f o r m i n g m a i n t e n a n c e o r r e p a i r w o r k o n u n i t s p r o d u c i n g i o n i s i n g r a d i a t i o n , t h e exposure rate on any part of the body exceeding 5 µS/h (0.5 mRem/h), -p e r s o n n e l p e r f o r m i n g a c t i v i t i e s u s u a l l y i n v o l v i n g r a d i o a c t i v e s u b s t a n c e s , w h e n i t i s l i k e l y t h a t the persons in question may receive more than 2 mS/year (0.2 Rem/year), -p e r

s o n n e l p e r f o r m i n g m a i n t e n a n c e a n d r e p a i r w o r k o n a r a d i o a c t i v e s o u r c e . 7.5.2 Use of Dosimeters Dosimeters are produced in different designs. The type to which the following rules are applicable is the ‘film badge’, containing a photographic film which shows, upon development, a certain blackening due to radiation received. This blackening is a measure of the dose received. Personnel is obliged to observe the following instructions regarding the use of the film badge: -d u r i n g w o r k i n g h o u r s t h e f i l m b a d g e m u s t b e c a r r i e d a s d e s c r i b e d ( t h e p o s i t i o n i s s t a t e d w h e n the film badge is provided), -w h e n t h e f i l m b a d g e i s n o t c a r r i e d , i t m u s t b e s o s t o r e d t h a t i t c a n n o t b e i r r a d i a t e d , -t h e p l a c e o f s t o r a g e m u s t b e c o o l a n d d r y , s i n c e m o i s t u r e a n d h i g h t e m p e r a t u r e m a y p r o d u c e incorrect measuring results, -i t i s f o r b i d d e n t o u s e a n o t h e r p e r s o n ’ s f i l m b a d g e . The dose measured by means of the film badge must be registered on a ‘registration card for personal radiation check’ by the safety officer.

Subject to restrictive legend on title pageSafety Instructions 2-14 9501 921 113XX CHP 002 01 008M I C R O W A V E R A D I A T I O N 8.1 General Microwaves are electromagnetic oscillations, having a frequency range lying between 300 MHz and 300 GHz. Dangerous microwaves are produced by high power devices, e.g. klystrons, magnetrons and TWTs. Microwaves are used in the following applications: -c o m m u n i c a t i o n s y s t e m s , -d e t e c t i o n s y s t e m s ( r a d a r ) , -m e a s u r i n g e q u i p m e n t . 8.2 Risks Direct exposure of the body to microwave radiation will cause: -a t e m p e r a t u r e r i s e o f t h e i n t e r n a l o r g a n s , i m p l y i n g t h a t , i n p a r t i c u l a r , o r g a n s h a v i n g a p o o r blood supply, such as the gall-bladder and the urinary tracts, may be damaged, -d e v e l o p m e n t o f t u r b i d i t y o f t h e e y e l e n s e s , -d a m a g e o f t h e r e p r o d u c t i v e o r g a n s . The degree of damage may vary considerably, depending on the intensity, frequency and duration of the radiation, thickness of bones, muscles and fat layers, the reflecting qualities of the skin, the absorption coefficient of the tissue exposed to radiation, the clothing and the irradiated surface. Intense heating may develop in small body cavities due to concentration of energy by resonance. 8.3 Permissible Radiation Level The starting point should always be, that the exposure of any part

of the body to microwave radiation, even of low power, should be avoided as much as possible. When a radar system is transmitting, a microwave radiation hazard exists around the antenna and in waveguide circuits. -S a f e a r e a s : under normal operational conditions there is no RADHAZ danger to personnel. In the vicinity of the antenna, the area below the plane through the foundation ring of the antenna can be considered as a safe area. -D a n g e r o u s a r e a s : when servicing or repair work has to be done close to the antenna, the following information must be observed: The dangerous areas are subdivided into four zones, dependent upon the power density (PD) of the radiation, see Fig. 2-8.

Safety Instructions 2-15 9501 921 113XX CHP 002 01 00 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageFig. 2-8 Permissible Radiation Level (v is the frequency of the radiation) Transference of this figure in more practical values, gives the following four zones of danger as an indication. Zone A: Extremely dangerous (PD > 20 mW/cm2). This area must not be entered by personnel when there is radar transmission. Zone B: Very dangerous (20 mW/cm2 > PD > 10 mW/cm2). This area should not be entered for periods longer than 10 minutes per hour when there is radar transmission (total exposure should not exceed 1 hour per day). Zone C: Dangerous (10 mW/cm2 > PD > 1 mW/cm2). This area should not be entered for periods longer than 1 hour per day when there is radar transmission. Zone D: Not dangerous (PD < 1 mW/cm2). Reflection from neighbouring objects must also be taken into account. 9L A S E R R A D I A T I O N 9.1 General A concentrated transfer of energy realised by a very narrow laser beam may cause damage to biological tissues, due to the development of heat when the radiation is absorbed. The eye lens may increase the effect of the radiation by a factor 105to 106,r e s u l t i n gi nb l i n ds p o t so n the retina within one microsecond. Radiation lying outside the visible light range (infrared and ultra-violet) carries an additional risk since one is not aware of the existence of radiation. High-power lasers may cause burns on the skin by absorption of energy. These are not only effected by the laser beam proper, but also and in particular random reflections. When the laser energy is absorbed by an inflammable agent, a fire may start. 9.2 Safe Distance The safe distance to a laser is the distance at which the radiation intensity of the beam has decreased to the so-called Safe Viewing Distance (SVD) value. At this distance there is no longer any danger for eyes and skin. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageSafety Instructions 2-18 9501 921 113XX CHP 002 01 009.4 Laser Goggles If there is a chance that during working with a laser system the eyes are exposed to a radiation intensity which exceeds the applicable MPE level, properly constructed laser goggles must be used. Laser goggles contain filters, having a certain optical density to reduce the radiation generated by a laser system. The filters must be robust and capable of dissipating the heat produced by radiation striking a small surface. The most widely used filter is the selective absorption filter which provides a satisfactory protection against radiation having a certain wavelength (n), but permits the passage of light of other parts of the spectrum, so as to allow observations to be made. 9.4.1 Optical Density (D λ) The optical density (or reduction), D λ,of the laser goggles applies to certain wavelength(s). Laser systems are capable of generating radiation of more than one wavelength, necessitating protective means which sufficiently reduce the radiation in question. If the radiation dose near the eye without laser goggles has an intensity of H (W/m2), the optical density of the filter required to reduce the radiation to the given MPE value is determined by the formula: The laser goggles must be provided with a clear indication concerning the wavelength for which they may be used and the optical density of the goggles. 10 ULTRAVIOLET RADIATIO

N 10.1 General UV-radiation is an electromagnetic oscillation phenomenon with a wavelength between approximately 100 nm and 380 nm. Radiation with a wavelength less than 180 nm is strongly absorbed by the air. Safety instructions are only applicable for wavelengths from 180 to 380 nm. 10.2 Risks The eyes are very susceptible to UV-radiation with wavelengths below 310 nm, the strongest effect appears at 270 nm. When a high amount is received, a very painful inflammation of the connective tissue and the cornea takes place (known as flash-eyes or shipyard eyes). It heals mostly within 24 to 28 hours without permanent damage. UV-radiation causes sunburn, and when a high amount is received, severe burning and blistering of the skin takes place.DλH MPE------------- log =

Subject to restrictive legend on title pageSafety Instructions 2-20 9501 921 113XX CHP 002 01 0013 BONDING ADHESIVES 13.1 General It is recommended that personnel applying bonding adhesives pay attention to safety when handling these items. 13.2 Epoxy Resin Adhesive Do not touch the uncured mixture to avoid skin irritation. 13.3 Rubber Contact Adhesives -R u b b e r c o n t a c t a d h e s i v e i s v e r y i n f l a m m a b l e . -K e e p c o n t a i n e r c l o s e d w h e n n o t i n u s e . -T h o r o u g h v e n t i l a t i o n o f t h e w o r k a r e a i s r e q u i r e d . -S m o k i n g o f n a k e d f l a m e s i n t h e v i c i n i t y o f t h e w o r k s p o t i s n o t a l l o w e d . -I n h a l a t i o n o f t h e v a p o u r m u s t b e a v o i d e d . 13.4 Cyanoacrylate Adhesive Cyanoacrylate adhesive is inflammable above 50 °C. Naked flames and the presence of hot objects when using this adhesive is not allowed. Uncured adhesives bonds immediately to the skin. Great care should be taken to avoid contact with fingers and particularly the eyes. Adhesives should be rinsed with water immediately, and NOT with a solvent. Vapour irritates the mucous membranes and particularly the eyes. 14 LOCKING AGENTS 14.1 General It is recommended that personnel applying locking agents pay attention to safety when handling these agents. 14.2 Safety Information Locking agent residue should be washed off with soap and water.

Safety Instructions 2-21 9501 921 113XX CHP 002 01 00 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title page15 HUMISEAL 1B31 15.1 General It is recommended that personnel, applying Humiseal 1B31, pay attention to safety during this part of the job. 15.2 Safety Information The main ingredient of Humiseal-thinner is toluene. Toluene is poisonous and inflammable, so see to good ventilation at the work spot and avoid naked flames. 16 BERYLLIUM OXIDE (BeO) 16.1 General It is recommended that personnel working with this material pay attention to safety during handling. Beryllium oxide can be used as heat conducting material under power devices. 16.2 Safety Information Beryllium oxide dust and fumes are highly toxic and admission to the body can result in serious injury or even death. Avoid inhalation and contact with open wounds. Tightening torques must be strictly observed due to the fact that the material is very brittle and particles are easily scattered in the open air. 17 TEFLON 17.1 General It is recommended that personnel working with this material pay attention to safety during handling. 17.2 Safety Information When teflon is heated above 200 °C, toxic vapours are released which can cause serious injury or even death. Pay strict attention to the following points during use: -p e r s o n n e l w o r k i n g w i t h t h i s m a t e r i a l ( c u t t i n g , s t r i p p i n g w i r e , e t c . ) s h o u l d not smoke during the job, -s m o k i n g a t t r
i b u t e s s h o u l d n o t b e c a r r i e d i n t h e w o r k c l o t h i n g n o r b e l e f t i n t h e w o r k p l a c e during the job,

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageSafety Instructions 2-22 9501 921 113XX CHP 002 01 00-m a t e r i a l s h o u l d b e s t o r e d i n c l o s e d p a c k a g i n g a n d w a s t e p r o d u c t s s h o u l d b e k e p t i n c l o s e d containers, -a f t e r h a n d l i n g t e f l o n , t h o r o u g h l y b r u s h o f f c l o t h e s a n d s c r u b f a c e a n d h a n d s . 18 SAFETY AND FIRST AID 18.1 General Because personnel working with electronic equipment are exposed to the hazard of high voltage, it is imperative that all safety instructions be consistently observed, and that each individual has a clear understanding of basic First Aid methods. For their own protection, and the protection of others, all maintenance personnel should become thoroughly familiar with the approved First Aid treatment of burns and shock. 18.2 Burns There are three principal degrees of burns, recognizable as follows: -a f i r s t d e g r e e b u r n c o l o u r s t h e s k i n , -a s e c o n d d e g r e e b u r n b l i s t e r s t h e s k i n , -a t h i r d d e g r e e b u r n c h a r s t h e f l e s h a n d f r e q u e n t l y p l a c e s t h e v i c t i m i n a s t a t e o f s h o c k accompanied by respiratory paralysis. 18.3 Respiratory Paralysis Respiratory paralysis in the victim can cause death within seconds, by suffocation. For this reason it is imperative that the approved method of artificial respiration be initiated immediately and

continued until the victim’s breathing is normal. A muscular spasm or unconsciousness may render the victim unable to free himself of the electric power. If this is the case, turn the power OFF immediately. WARNING: DO NOT TOUCH HIM, OR YOU MAY SHARE HIS PREDICAMENT! If the power cannot be turned OFF immediately, very carefully loop a dry rope, article of clothing, length of strong cloth, or a rolled-up newspaper around the victim and pull him free of the power. Carefully avoid touching him or his clothing during this action. The moment he is clear of the power, place him in a reclining position, cover him with a blanket (or newspapers) to keep him warm, and start artificial respiration. At the first opportunity, enlist help in the summoning of a doctor. If a doctor cannot be summoned, transport the victim to the doctor, infirmary, or hospital. Be sure that the victim is kept well covered and warm while awaiting professional aid and treatment.

Subject to restrictive legend on title pageSafety Instructions 2-24 9501 921 113XX CHP 002 01 0018.4.2 Exhaled Air Method (kiss of life) If the victim has stopped breathing, then: -l a y t h e v i c t i m f a c e u p w a r d s o n t h e f l o o r , -u n b u t t o n h i s c l o t h i n g : c o l l a r , n e c k - t i e a n d r e m o v e h i s b e l t , -w i t h y o u r f i n g e r s r e m o v e a n y f o r e i g n o b j e c t s f r o m h i s m o u t h ( f a l s e t e e t h , e t c . ) , -t a k e u p p o s i t i o n b e s i d e t h e v i c t i m ’ s h e a d , p r e f e r a b l y o n h i s l e f t , -t u r n h i s h e a d o v e r b a c k w a r d s a n d chin up , This action is vital, for it opens the victim’s passage. Act as follows: -S l i p y o u r l e f t h a n d u n d e r t h e v i c t i m ’ s n e c k a n d r a i s e i t , a l l o w i n g t h e h e a d t o s a g backwards. -W i t h y o u r r i g h t h a n d , p i n c h t h e v i c t i m ’ s n o s e s h u t a n d u s e t h e r e m a i n d e r o f y o u r r i g h t hand to apply pressure to the victim’s forehead, thus keeping in the ‘chin-up’ position. Fig. 2-10 Mouth-to-mouth Method Applied by One Person -a f t e r h a v i n g f i l l e d y o u r l u n g s c o m p l e t e l y , p r e s s y o u r o p e n m o u t h a c r o s s t h e v i c t i m ’ s m o u t h t o produce a perfect air seal, then empty your lungs with force into his, until the victim’s chest expands, -t h e n w i t h d r a w y o

u r m o u t h t o a l l o w t h e v i c t i m t o b r e a t h o u t , t h i s w i l l h a p p e n s p o n t a n e o u s l y because his chest will contract elastically, -r e p e a t t h i s m e t h o d o f p u m p i n g u p t h e v i c t i m ’ s l u n g s a n d l e t t i n g t h e m d e f l a t e a b o u t 12 times per minute , and continue until the victim will spontaneously breath in and out at a steady rhythm and not too faintly, or until medical assistance arrives. 9501 921 113XX FIG 018 01 00

Subject to restrictive legend on title page18.4.3 External Cardiac Massage If the victim’s heart has stopped beating, then: -l a y t h e v i c t i m o n h i s b a c k o n t h e g r o u n d o r o n s o m e o t h e r firm surface, -p l a c e t h e h e e l o f o n e h a n d , w i t h t h e o t h e r o n t o p o f i t , o n t h e l o w e r p a r t o f t h e s t e r n u m ( b r e a s t bone) in the mid line of the chest, see warning below, -a p p l y f i r m p r e s s u r e v e r t i c a l l y d o w n w a r d s a i d e d b y t h e w e i g h t o f t h e b o d y , a b o u t 60 times a minute , -a t t h e e n d o f e a c h p r e s s u r e s t r o k e , t h e h a n d s a r e t o b e l i f t e d s l i g h t l y t o a l l o w f u l l r e c o i l o f t h e victim’s chest, -s u f f i c i e n t p r e s s u r e s h o u l d b e u s e d t o d e p r e s s t h e s t e r n u m a n i n c h o r s o t o w a r d s t h e v e r t e b r a l column (spine), Fig. 2-11 Chest Massage Applied by One Person -a r t i f i c i a l r e s p i r a t i o n m u s t c o n t i n u e s i m u l t a n e o u s l y w i t h e x t e r n a l c a r d i a c m a s s a g e a t t h e r a t e o f about 15 compressions of the heart to one inflation of the lungs, -m a s s a g e s h o u l d c o n t i n u e u n t i l t h e v i c t i m ’ s p u l s e i s c l e a r l y f e l t a n d t h e c o l o u r r e t u r n s t o normal, or until medical assistance

arrives. WARNING: Donotattempt cardiac massage if there is obvious damage to the victim’s chest wall. If artificial respiration is done simultaneously with external cardiac massage by two persons the rate is about 5 compressions of the heart to two inflations of the lungs. For position see Fig. 2-12. 9501 921 113XX FIG 019 01 00

Subject to restrictive legend on title pageSafety Instructions 2-26 9501 921 113XX CHP 002 01 00Fig. 2-12 Person on the Right Applies External Heart Massage; Person on the Left Gives the Kiss of Life 19 PRECAUTIONS TO AVOID EQUIPMENT DAMAGE 19.1 General When performing maintenance, the possibility arises that conditions can occur which bring damage to the equipment. 19.2 Types of Damage Conditions In this paragraph some of the more common types of damage conditions are described. -I n c o r r e c t u s e o f i n s t r u m e n t s , i n s t r u m e n t l e a d s o r t o o l s , i m p r o p e r m a t i n g o f c o n n e c t o r s , modules, fittings and/or couplings. -S e r v i c e a c t i o n s i n h i g h v o l t a g e c i r c u i t s w i t h o u t d i s c h a r g i n g r e s i d u a l v o l t a g e s a f t e r t h e h i g h voltage is switched off. -C r e a t i n g c o n d i t i o n s i n w h i c h p o l a r i t y i n v e r s i o n s o f l i q u i d t a n t a l u m c a p a c i t o r s c a n o c c u r . Under this condition these capacitors may explode, expelling a caustic electrolyte which may not only injure personnel but also damage other components. -T h e u s e o f m a g n e t s o r m a g n e t i c m a t e r i a l s ( t o o l s ) i n t h e v i c i n i t y o f f o r i n s t a n c e c i r c u l a t o r u n i t s , can cause permanent damage to the magnetic characteristics of these units and lead to system loss or degradation. -I n c o m p

e t e n t m a i n t e n a n c e i n t h e v i c i n i t y o f m o v i n g p a r t s s u c h a s : g e a r w h e e l s , r o t a t i n g s h a f t s , couplings, hydraulic actuators, etc. can damage the driving system. -E S D - s e n s i t i v e p a r t s ( i . e . a l l P C B s ) m u s t b e h a n d l e d w i t h s p e c i a l p r e c a u t i o n s See paragraph 19.3. 9501 921 113XX FIG 020 01 00

Safety Instructions 2-27 9501 921 113XX CHP 002 01 00 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title page19.3 ESD Sensitive Parts ESD sensitive parts or assemblies will be destroyed by a sudden discharge of static electricity. All modern designs use ESD sensitive parts. In practise all electronic circuitry must be considered as ESD sensitive. Handle ESD sensitive parts or assemblies very carefully and apply the following measures (see Fig. 2-13): -a l l p e r s o n n e l s h o u l d b e e a r t h e d u s i n g a s p e c i a l b r a c e l e t , -w o r k i n g s u r f a c e s m u s t b e e l e c t r i c a l l y d i s s i p a t i v e ( s u r f a c e r e s i s t a n c e o f 1 05Ω to 109 Ω) and earthed, -c h e c k a t r e g u l a r i n t e r v a l s t h e r e s i s t a n c e o f t h e b r a c e l e t s a n d t h e s u r f a c e o f t h e w o r k i n g t a b l e , -u s e E S D s a f e t o o l s ( i f i n d o u b t , e a r t h t h e t o o l ) , -k e e p a l l s y n t h e t i c m a t e r i a l s / o b j e c t s a w a y f r o m E S D s e n s i t i v e p a r t s a n d w o r k i n g a r e a s , -a l w a y s u s e E S D s a f e p a c k a g e m a t e r i a l s s u c h a s p l a s t i c b a g s a n d C a b e l e k b o x e s . U n i t s o r P C B s assembled with ESD sensitive parts and supplied by Signaal, are always marked by an ESD sticker (see Fig. 2-14). Before opening package: -g r o u n d y o u r s e l f , -u s e E S D s a f e t o o l s . Fig. 2-13 ESD Safe W
ork Area1 MΩ (2)220 K Ω 1 MΩ EARTHSOLDERING IRON (1)DISSIPATIVE TABLE SURFACE BRACELET NOTES: 2. RESISTANCE OF CONNECTING WIRE1. EARTHED SOLDERING IRON, WHERE NECESSARY9501 921 113XX FIG 021 01 00

Subject to restrictive legend on title page Introduction to FFP 3-1 9501 817 913XX CHP 003 00 009501 916 007XX CHP 001 00 00CHAPTER 3 Presentation of the Procedures 1I N T R O D U C T I O N Fault finding procedures (FFP) are presented in the form of flow charts containing symbols and text. The symbols which are used in FFPs are described in para 2. An explanation of frequently used terms, location designation, number representation etc. is given in para 2.1. 2F A U L T F I N D I N G S Y M B O L S The following symbols are used in FFPs: 1 32 4This symbol contains a question with two possible answers: -Y e s ( e x i t 3 ) , -N o ( e x i t 2 o r i n e x c e p t i o n a l c a s e s e x i t 4 ) . Entry is 1 or 4. Note: Only the first question symbol on each page will be provided with the characters Y and N.Question (decision) The contents of this symbol is always an instruction for the maintainer.Instruction Reference The contents of all but the first (which has the name START) is a cross-reference. This cross-reference is an entry from another part of the procedure. When used as an exit they cross-refer directly to another chapter.Three reference symbols are available:

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title page Introduction to FFP 3-2 9501 817 913XX CHP 003 00 00 9501 916 007XX CHP 001 00 002.1 Textual Information in the Flow Charts 2.1.1 Introduction This paragraph contains a number of explanations the maintainer needs to know in order to carry out the FFPs. The following items are described: -l o c a t i o n d e s i g n a t i o n , -i n d i c a t i o n d e f e c t i v e L R U s , -n o t e s . 2.1.2 Location Designation All actions required by the maintainer are preceded by the location designation, indicating the location where the actions have to be carried out. The location designation contains at least the cabinet name and the panel indication. When designating a component on a printed circuit board in a panel of a cabinet the following notation is used: <CABINET> - <PANEL> - <PCB> - <COMPONENT>The contents of this symbol provides a cross-reference to the continuation of the same procedure on the same or one of the subsequent pages. This symbol is used as reference to documentation. This can be another category of the handbook set, another section or documentation of non Signaal manufacturer. The contents of this symbol is in general additional information.Flag Safety Safety symbols can be added to the FFP to indicate dangerous situations (see chapter 2).

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title page Introduction to FFP 3-3 9501 817 913XX CHP 003 00 009501 916 007XX CHP 001 00 00When designating a pushbutton on a panel of a cabinet the following notation is used: <CABINET> - <PANEL> - <AREA> - <PUSHBUTTON> Where: <CABINET> = abbreviation of cabinet name (e.g. RAC (radar cabinet)), <PANEL> = panel indication (e.g. C or suitable name), <PCB> = position code of printed circuit board (e.g. A-27), <COMPONENT> = component identification (e.g. LED GR10), <AREA> = name of the relevant area in which the pushbutton is located or the group name (e.g. TECHNICAL CONTROL), <PUSHBUTTON> = component identification and the name of the pushbutton (e.g. SK1 LOCAL). 2.1.3 Indication Defective LRUs Faulty LRUs are indicated by their location designation. If a number of LRUs in the same rack is isolated, the cabinet and panel indications will be given once only: RAC - A - C-27 - C-25 2.1.4 Notes To give additional information about the contents of a symbol a number with a bracket is placed within or next to the symbol, (e.g. 1). This number refers to a note which is always given on the same page.

Subject to restrictive legend on title page Introduction to FFP 4-1 9501 817 913XX CHP 004 00 009501 916 007XX CHP 001 00 00CHAPTER 4 Fault Finding Methods 1I N T R O D U C T I O N Generally, fault finding is achieved by making use of all switches, lamps, displays, etc. of the system. In addition the maintainer may apply various techniques to isolate the fault. In the following paragraphs a number of methods are explained which often form part of the procedures. The following methods will be described: -f a u l t f i n d i n g b y m e a n s o f s o f t w a r e p r o g r a m s , -f a u l t f i n d i n g b y m e a n s o f e l i m i n a t i o n ( l o a d f a u l t ) , -f a u l t f i n d i n g b y m e a n s o f s p a r e u n i t r e p l a c e m e n t , -f a u l t f i n d i n g b y m e a n s o f m e a s u r e m e n t s . 2F A U L T F I N D I N G B Y M E A N S O F S O F T W A R E P R O G R A M S The system features hardware and software BIT facilities as an aid in fault localisation down to LRU level. The way in which test programs are loaded is described in part 6B(3), test package manual. The way in which other programs are loaded is described in part 3, operating instructions. 3F A U L T F I N D I N G B Y M E A N S O F E L I M I N A T I O N ( l o a d f a u l t ) When in a procedure (e.g. power supplies) a load fault has been established which is caused by one of a series of Printed Circuit Boards (PCBs) the following method may be applied: -R e

m o v e h a l f o f t h e i n d i c a t e d P C B s ( s w i t c h o f f f i r s t ) . -I f t h e f a u l t d o e s n o t r e - o c c u r , r e - i n s e r t t h e P C B s o n e b y o n e u n t i l t h e f a u l t o c c u r s a g a i n . T h e last re-inserted PCB causes the fault. -I f t h e f a u l t i s s t i l l p r e s e n t r e - i n s e r t t h e P C B s a n d r e m o v e t h e o t h e r h a l f o f t h e i n d i c a t e d P C B s one by one until the fault has disappeared. The last removed PCB is faulty. Note: A fault can also be caused by a reduced capacity of a power supply unit. In that case the fault will disappear after the removal of a number of random PCBs. Remove and replace the relevant power supply unit. Before any removal or repair activity is attempted chapter 2, safety instructions must be consulted. 4F A U L T F I N D I N G B Y M E A N S O F S P A R E U N I T R E P L A C E M E N T When in a procedure an LRU is replaced by a spare, there are two possibilities: -T h e s a m e f a u l t o c c u r s a g a i n . I n t h a t c a s e t h e r e p l a c e d L R U i s n o t f a u l t y .

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title page Introduction to FFP 4-2 9501 817 913XX CHP 004 00 00 9501 916 007XX CHP 001 00 00-T h e f a u l t h a s d i s a p p e a r e d . I n t h a t c a s e t h e r e l e v a n t L R U i s f a u l t y . Note: When replacements are done, adjustments, such as the setting of U-links, should be taken into account (see part 5). When spares are not available or the time needed to get the spare is too long it is possible to borrow an LRU from the same part of the (sub)system. It is the maintainer’s responsibility to use either a spare LRU or to use a ‘borrowed’ LRU. Before any removal or repair activity is attempted chapter 2, safety instructions must be consulted. 5F A U L T F I N D I N G B Y M E A N S O F M E A S U R E M E N T S 5.1 Introduction Before a measurement is made all safety instructions must be observed (see chapter 2, safety instructions). Instructions concerning performing of a measurement will contain the following information: -l o c a t i o n d e s i g n a t i o n , -p i n s o r p o i n t s o n o r b e t w e e n w h i c h t h e m e a s u r e m e n t i s t o b e m a d e , -m e a s u r i n g i n s t r u m e n t p l u s , w h e n n e c e s s a r y , t h e s e t t i n g s , -t h e m e a s u r e m e n t t h a t m u s t b e m a d e . When a measurement is made the following general remarks should be taken into account: -E S D - s e n s i t i v e c o m p o n e n t s ( a l l e l e c t r o n i c u n i t s

a n d c o m p o n e n t s ) m u s t b e h a n d l e d w i t h s p e c i a l precautions. A maintainer must be connected to ground via a wrist-bracelet (with a 1 MegaOhm resistive circuit) when handling these components. Measuring or test equipment first must be connected to the ground of the device under test, before any other connection is made to the ESD-sensitive components. Before connecting any probe of measuring or test equipment to ESD-sensitive circuits, the probe must be discharged against ground. Exchanged and spare ESD-sensitive components must always be packed in their original packaging. Never put these components without packaging on isolated surfaces, unless an ESD conductive surface mat is used. -W h e n m e a s u r i n g s i g n a l s a t a P C B ( a n d n o t e s t b u s o r t e s t p o i n t i s a v a i l a b l e ) a n e x t e n d e r c a r d must be used. -W h e n a m e a s u r e m e n t i s t o b e m a d e a t a n e x t e n d e d r a c k o r p a n e l t h i s p a r t w i l l n o l o n g e r b e cooled. -M e a s u r e m e n t s a t a n o p e n r a c k o r p a n e l m a y b e d a n g e r o u s d u e t o d a n g e r o u s v o l t a g e s ( a b o v e 42 V). -B e f o r e w o r k i n g o n h i g h v o l t a g e s u p p l i e s t h e c a p a c i t o r s m u s t b e d i s c h a r g e d w i t h a r e s i s t o r o f 150Ω 20 W or discharge rod. -E v e n w h e n t h e s y s t e m i s s w i t c h e d o f f v o l t a g e s m a y s t i l l b e p r e s e n t i n t h e s

y s t e m ( r e f e r e n c e voltages, relay voltages, capacitive charges). Therefore care must be taken when measurements are made, even when the system is switched off. -W h e n a s y s t e m i s s w i t c h e d o f f ( e . g . b e f o r e a r e p l a c e m e n t ) , i n f o r m a t i o n l o s s m a y o c c u r . -W h e n f o r a m e a s u r e m e n t o n l y p i n o r p o i n t h a s b e e n g i v e n , t h e m e a s u r e m e n t i s t o b e m a d e w i t h

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title page Introduction to FFP 4-3 9501 817 913XX CHP 004 00 009501 916 007XX CHP 001 00 00respect to ground. -W h e n n o s p e c i f i c t o l e r a n c e h a s b e e n g i v e n f o r a s i g n a l v a l u e t o b e m e a s u r e d , a n a c c u r a c y o f + and - 10% must be maintained. -M e a s u r i n g i n s t r u m e n t s m a y i n f l u e n c e t h e s i g n a l s m e a s u r e d d u e t o t h e i n p u t i m p e d a n c e o f t h e measuring instruments. -T e s t p o i n t s , w h e n n o t p r o v i d e d w i t h a n a m e ( e . g . f r o n t p a n e l : I N P U T , , e t c . ) , a r e i n d i c a t e d as follows: ZW - black - TP0 = 0, 10, 20, -- BR - brown - TP1 = 1, 11, 21, -- RD - red - TP2 = 2, 12, 22, -- OR - orange - TP3 = 3, 13, 23, -- GL - yellow - TP4 = 4, 14, 24, -- GN - green - TP5 = 5, 15, 25, -- BL - blue - TP6 = 6, 16, 26, -- VI - violet - TP7 = 7, 17, 27, -- GS - grey - TP8 = 8, 18, 28, -- WT - white - TP9 = 9, 19, 29, -- Examples: BTS-A-A-3-BR = Brown test point on PCB on position A-3 of panel A of the Bus Terminal Server (BTS). BTS-A-A-3-TP2 = Red test point on PCB on position A-3 of panel A of the BTS. -F o r t e s t i n g a n d m o n i t o r i n g a T T W ( T e l e T y p e W r i t e r ) c a n b e c o n n e c t e d t o t h e L W 0 8 r a d a r system. An available PIOD (Portable Input Output Device) can be used for these purposes. The term TTW is used throughout the documentation

and software outputs and controls. 5.2 Voltage Measurements -B e f o r e a v o l t a g e m e a s u r e m e n t i s m a d e t h e r e m a r k s o f t h e p r e v i o u s p a r a g r a p h m u s t b e t a k e n into account. -P r i o r t o e a c h m e a s u r e m e n t i t i s r e c o m m e n d e d t h a t t h e m e a s u r i n g i n s t r u m e n t i s s e t t o i t s h i g h e s t range in order to prevent possible damage. -V o l t a g e s a b o v e 1 0 0 0 V a r e o n l y t o b e m e a s u r e d w i t h s p e c i a l h i g h v o l t a g e l e a d s . 5.3 Resistance Measurements -B e f o r e a r e s i s t a n c e m e a s u r e m e n t i s m a d e t h e r e m a r k s o f p a r a 5 . 1 m u s t b e t a k e n i n t o a c c o u n t . -F o r t h e m e a s u r e m e n t o f r e s i s t a n c e i n t h e s y s t e m i t i s n e c e s s a r y t o e n s u r e t h a t a l l v o l t a g e s supplied to the relevant circuits are switched off. -I f t h e c i r c u i t t o b e m e a s u r e d a l s o c o n t a i n s c a p a c i t o r s l o w r e s i s t a n c e r e a d i n g m a y b e i n i t i a l l y experienced due to the charging of the capacitors.

Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-1 1-1 9501 817 924XX CHP 001 01 009501 916 007XX CHP 001 00 00CHAPTER 1 Introduction The handbook part 6B(3), test package manual, provides information about the various facilities which are available on the LW08 system for testing and fault finding. The handbook is sub-divided as follows: Section 1, Introduction This section provides information about the structure of part 6B(3) and contains a reference list. This reference list shows which tests are used or can be used to test a certain Line Replaceable Unit (LRU) and where these tests are described. The reference list is given in chapter 2. Section 2, Hardware Test Facilities This section describes for each cabinet the available hardware test facilities. Section 3, Software Test Facilities This section describes the test facilities which make use of the built-in micro processor units. These facilities are given in the following sub-sections: -S e c t i o n 3 - 1 , S o f t w a r e t e s t f a c i l i t i e s A n t e n n a C o n t r o l U n i t ( A C U ) , -S e c t i o n 3 - 2 , S o f t w a r e t e s t f a c i l i t i e s F r e q u e n c y C o n t r o l a n d T i m i n g U n i t ( F C T U ) . Note: For testing and monitoring a TTW (Tele Type Writer) can be connected to the LW08 radar system. An available PIOD (Portable Input Output Device) can be used for these purposes. The term TTW is used throughout the documentation, software output
