Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-2 1-1 9501 817 925XX CHP 001 00 009501 916 007XX CHP 001 00 00CHAPTER 1 Introduction This section describes the hardware test facilities of the LW08 radar system. This information is given in the following chapters: -C h a p t e r 2 A n t e n n a s y s t e m ( A N T ) , -C h a p t e r 3 T r a n s m i t t e r c a b i n e t ( T X C ) , -C h a p t e r 4 R e c e i v e r c a b i n e t ( R X C ) , -C h a p t e r 5 C o o l i n g c a b i n e t ( C O C ) . For information about testing of the Hydraulic Power Unit (HPU), reference is made to the ‘Handbook for the Hydraulic Power Unit’ (Parker).
 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-2 1-2 9501 817 925XX CHP 001 00 00 9501 916 007XX CHP 001 00 00

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-2 2-2 9501 817 925XX CHP 002 00 00 9501 916 007XX CHP 001 00 00BRAKE RELEASED LEFT/RIGHT This is a three-positions switch, which is used to release the left or right cylinder brake during the manual control mode. The brakes can only be released when the NORMAL/PUMP OFF switch is in the NORMAL position. CAUTION: Before the brakes are released by this switch, the potentiometer CYL.MOTION UP/DOWN must be put to the middle position. CYL. MOTION UP/DOWN Potentiometer to control the servo valves of the hydraulic cylinders during the manual control mode. By using the potentiometer the cylinders can be moved to the desired position. The brake concerned must be released by means of the BRAKE RELEASE switch.

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-2 3-1 9501 817 925XX CHP 003 00 009501 916 007XX CHP 001 00 00CHAPTER 3 Transmitter Cabinet 1I N T R O D U C T I O N This chapter describes the hardware test facilities of the transmitter cabinet which can be used for fault finding and testing. The test facilities of the transmitter cabinet are given per rack or panel. The following panels or racks are provided with test facilities: -p o w e r s u p p l y a n d d i s t r i b u t i o n u n i t ( p a n e l A ) , s e e p a r a 2 , -p r o t e c t i o n u n i t ( p a n e l C ) , s e e p a r a 3 , -s u b - m o d u l a t o r ( p a n e l D ) , s e e p a r a 4 , -s t a b i l i s a t i o n a n d t e s t p a n e l ( p a n e l U 1 ) , s e e p a r a 5 , -c o n s t a n t c u r r e n t s o u r c e ( p a n e l F ) , s e e p a r a 6 . 2P O W E R S U P P L Y A N D D I S T R I B U T I O N U N I T 2.1 Introduction The hardware test facilities of the power supply and distribution unit concern only indications. 2.2 Indications +24 V1 These lamps indicate that the unstabilised 24 V +24 V2 supply voltages are present. 440 V, 3 ph, 50/60 Hz Three lamps to indicate that the ships supply voltage is present. 115 V, 50/60 Hz, AC Lamp to indicate that the anti-condensation heating is switched on. The lamp is on if the transmitter cabinet is switched off. 3P R O T E C T I O N U N I T 3.1 Introduction The protection unit is provided with the following hardware test fac
ilities: -i n d i c a t i o n s , -t e s t s w i t c h e s , -b u i l t - i n t e s t s .

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-2 3-4 9501 817 925XX CHP 003 00 00 9501 916 007XX CHP 001 00 003.3 Test Switches The protection unit is provided with the following switches: TEST TWT This switch is on the local control panel. The function is described in para 3.4. A/09-SK1 This switch is situated on card A/09 in the protection unit. For test purposes a low PRF (PRF/16) can be switched on or a single transmitter pulse (one shot) can be given. The switch has three positions: -u p p e r p o s i t i o n , P R F N O R M A L , -m i d d l e p o s i t i o n , P R F / 1 6 , -l o w e r p o s i t i o n , O N E S H O T .RXC-F-B-A/16 RXC-F-B-A/17 RXC-F-B-A/19 RXC-F-B-A/20 RXC-F-B-A/22 RXC-F-B-A/24F6.2.2, Sh2 F6.2.2, Sh4 F6.3.2, Sh2 F6.3.2, Sh4 F6.1, Sh5 F6.3.1, Sh3 PRF RXC-D-E-A/24 or RXC-D-E-A/26 RXC-D-E-A/23 RXC-D-E-A/19F1.3, Sh3,4 F1.3, Sh2 F8.1, Sh4 CIRC WAT FLOW Pump COC-M1 TXC-G-SK11F7.3, Sh1 F8.1, Sh6 COOLING General indication for error in cooling system. See error reports on cooling cabinet. F8.1, Sh5 WATER RES Heat exchanger or water filters in cooling cabinet. Purity meter COC-ME1F7.3, Sh2 F8.1, Sh5 TEST SET NOISE FIGURE or OUTPUT POWER error report on radar monitor F8.2, Sh1 WGD Waveguide drier COC-U2 Hose between COC and TXCF7.4, Sh2 ANT General indication for error in antenna control. See error reports on RXC-C (Antenna Control Unit) MAN ALOFT SWITCHIf both switches are in NO MAN ALOFT position: MAS(109) or MAS(110) F

8.1, Sh3 Indication Possible failure See part 6A 1) These faults must be solved in the following order: HV<90%, HV>MAX, I-AVER, GRID MOD, CCS, I-HELIX, I-ANODE Fig. 3-1 Fault Indications on the Local Control Panel (continued)

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-2 3-5 9501 817 925XX CHP 003 00 009501 916 007XX CHP 001 00 00A/09-SK2 Spring-loaded switch on card A/09 in the protection unit. The switch is used to produce a single transmitter pulse if switch A/09-SK1 is in position ONE SHOT. 3.4 Built-in Tests The protection unit is provided with a test for the TWT protection circuits. This test is executed if pushbutton TEST TWT is pressed (in the STAND-BY mode). The I-ANODE and I-HELIX LEDs on the LCP must illuminate. In this way the following hardware is tested: -T X C - G - T 4 , -T X C - C - A / 1 2 ( a n o d e a n d h e l i x c u r r e n t p r o t e c t i o n ) , -T X C - C - A / 1 5 ( a n o d e a n d h e l i x c u r r e n t p r o t e c t i o n ) . On the LCP the error reports can be reset with pushbutton RESET. 4S U B - M O D U L A T O R 4.1 Introduction The hardware test facilities of the sub-modulator only consist of indications. 4.2 Indications The sub-modulator is provided with the following indications: GM AV If LED is on, sub-modulator operates normally (Grid-Modulator Available). If the LED is off, error report GRID MOD on the LCP will be present. For possible failures, see para 3.2. Meter ME1 With this meter and selector switch the following values can be measured: -T W T f i l a m e n t c u r r e n t , -T W T f i l a m e n t v o l t a g e , -n e g a t i v e g r i d v o l t a g e ( - 7 5 0 V ) , -p o s i t i v e g r i d v o l t a g e

( c l i p p e r v o l t a g e ) . The values must be within the tolerances as indicated on the text plate. 5S T A B I L I S A T I O N A N D T E S T P A N E L 5.1 Introduction The stabilisation and test panel is provided with the following test facilities: -i n d i c a t i o n s , -t e s t p o i n t s .

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-2 3-6 9501 817 925XX CHP 003 00 00 9501 916 007XX CHP 001 00 005.2 Indications The stabilisation and test panel is provided with the following indications: STAB TUBE Meter with selector switch. During STAND BY, the meter must indicate: -< 8 0 S D i n p o s i t i o n I H E L I X T W T . During transmission, the meter must indicate: -< 8 0 S D i n p o s i t i o n I H E L I X T W T , -> 1 0 S D i n p o s i t i o n V A N O D E T W T . V CATHODE TWT Meter to measure the cathode voltage. During transmission the meter must read 80 ± 4 SD. HV AVER CURR Meter to measure the average high-voltage current. The current is measured at the primary of the high voltage transformer. During transmission the meter must read 50 ± 15 SD. 5.3 Test Points The stabilisation and test panel is provided with the following test points: TP1 Between TP1 (+) and TP3 (-) the cathode voltage can be measured (1 V - 1 kV). During transmission the voltage must be between 38 V and 42 V. TP2 Between TP2 and TP4 the filament voltage of the stabilisation tube TXC-E-B1 can be measured. The voltage must be between 5.7 and 6.3 V AC. TP3 See TP1. TP4 See TP2. TP5 The voltage between TP5 (-) and TP6 (+) must be 9.5 V (adjustment of stabilisation circuit). TP6 The voltage between TP6 (+) and TP8 (-) must be 100 V (supply voltage for stabilisation circuit). TP7 Between TP7 (+) and TP8 (-) the grid voltage of the stabilisation tube can
be measured. This voltage must be about 0 V. TP8 Ground. TP9 The voltage between TP9 (+) and TP10 (-) must be 9.5 V (adjustment of stabilisation circuit).

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-2 3-7 9501 817 925XX CHP 003 00 009501 916 007XX CHP 001 00 00TP10 The voltage between TP10 (-) and TP8 (+) must be 100 V (supply voltage for stabilisation circuit). 6C O N S T A N T C U R R E N T S O U R C E 6.1 Introduction To test the constant current source a meter with switch is present. 6.2 Indications On the front panel of the constant current source a meter with switch is present for measuring the focussing voltage and focussing current. The following values must be measured: I FOCUS 5 times the value of I-focus, as mentioned on the TWT ( ±2 SD). U FOCUS < 100 SD (the reading can vary due to warming up of the focus coil).
 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-2 3-8 9501 817 925XX CHP 003 00 00 9501 916 007XX CHP 001 00 00

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-2 4-3 9501 817 925XX CHP 004 01 009501 916 007XX CHP 001 00 00Simulation of targets is described in section 3/2 of this handbook part (software test facilities frequency control and timing unit). 3.4 Built-in Tests By means of the TEST GENERATOR switches a noise signal can be injected into the air-receiver channel and the SLS receiver channel. Dependent on the position of the LEVEL switch, the signal level is -15 dBm or -55 dBm. The test generator can be used to check the operation of SLS. For this the AGC voltage must be measured on card RXC-B-A-A/04-TP3-1 (AI AGC PC). The test switches must be in position ON and UPPER LEVEL. The AGC voltage must be measured during SLS switched on and SLS switched off (on LCP). If SLS is operating correct, the difference between the two AGC voltages may not exceed 0.5 V. 4A N T E N N A C O N T R O L U N I T 4.1 Introduction The antenna control unit is provided with the following hardware test facilities: -i n d i c a t i o n s , -t e s t p o i n t s , -t e s t c o n n e c t o r s . 4.2 Indications All status and error reports concerning the antenna stabilisation and antenna bearing drive, can be displayed on the ANLED display. All these reports and also instructions for control of the ANLED display are summarised in section 3/1 of this handbook part (software test facilities antenna control unit). 4.3 Test Points The front panel of the antenna control u

nit is provided with the following test points: GO/NO GO In case of a time-out of the micro processor, the output GND data of the micro processor are blocked by means of a firmware reset signal (FWRES) and an error report is sent to the data handling and transmitter cabinet (ANT fail). For test purposes these protection and reports can be suppressed by connecting the test points GO/NO GO and GND with each other. This provision is only used for factory tests. PRESS HPU The voltage on these test points is proportional to the GND hydraulic pressure of the HPU (1 V equals 30 bar).

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-2 4-4 9501 817 925XX CHP 004 01 00 9501 916 007XX CHP 001 00 00SERVO Outputs (SAO) for a servo analyser, for roll (Qe) and ANALYSER pitch (Eie). These test points are only used for factory Qe SAO tests. Eie SAO Qe SAI Not used (SAI). Eie SAI REGISTRATION On these test points (Qe/GND or Eie/GND) a brush recorder Qe/GND can be connected to register the servo errors for roll Eie/GND (Qe) or pitch (Eie). The servo errror, which is normally only present for the software, is fed via an extra D/A-converter to these test points. See also section 3/1 of this handbook part (software test facilities antenna control unit), chapter 2, para 3.3.3. 4.4 Test Connectors The front panel of the antenna control unit is provided with the following test connector: JOYSTICK On this connector a joy stick can be connected to control the platform to a certain position. The control voltages from the joystick are added to the operational control voltages from the servo amplifiers. So the joystick may only be used if the stabilisation is switched off. For joystick control the brakes on the hydraulic cylinders must be released, as described in section 3/1 of this handbook part (software testfacilities antenna control unit). MON/TRIG Connectors for an oscilloscope. Via these connectors digital data can be displayed via a D/A converter in the antenna control unit. These connectors are only used for factory tests. MONIT

OR Connector for a logic state analyser. This connector is provided for factory testing. PIOD Connector for a PIOD/ teletypewriter. Via this connector error reports can be displayed/printed and commands can be given. Further see section 3/1 of this handbook part (software testfacilities antenna control unit). 5F R E Q U E N C Y C O N T R O L A N D T I M I N G U N I T 5.1 Introduction The frequency control and timing unit is provided with the following hardware test facilities: -t e s t s w i t c h e s , -t e s t c o n n e c t o r s .

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-2 4-5 9501 817 925XX CHP 004 01 009501 916 007XX CHP 001 00 005.2 Test Switches On the timing rack in the FCTU (panel D-E) test switch LIU EN/DIS is available. Normally this switch is in position EN (enable). In position DIS (disable) the LIU-interface card will block all data to and from the IU-bus. 5.3 Test Connectors The timing rack (panel D-E) is provided with the following test connectors: PIOD Connector for a PIOD/teletypewriter. Via this connector error reports can be displayed/printed and commands can be given. Further see section 3/2 of this handbook part (software testfacilities frequency control and timing unit). MONITOR Connector for a logic state analyser. This connector is provided for factory testing. SCOPE Connectors for an oscilloscope. Via these connectors MON/TRIG digital data can be displayed via a D/A converter in the timing rack. These connectors are only used for factory tests. SPR65/115 On this connector a pre-sync pulse is present; 65 µs pre-sync for short pulse and 115 µs pre-sync for long pulse. IF TEST On this connector the 30 MHz IF signal from the frequency control unit is available. This output can be used to generated simulated targets. This is realised by connecting the IF output via an adjustable attenuator to the IF TEST input on the receiver rack. Simulation of targets is described in section 3/2 of this handbook part (software test facilities frequenc

y control and timing unit). RF TEST On this connector the RF signal from the frequency control unit is available. This RF signal is the pulse to be transmitted. 6V I D E O P R O C E S S O R 6.1 Introduction The video processor is provided with the following hardware test facilities: -i n d i c a t i o n s , -t e s t c o n n e c t o r s , -b u i l t - i n t e s t s .

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-2 4-6 9501 817 925XX CHP 004 01 00 9501 916 007XX CHP 001 00 006.2 Indications Behind the front panel of the video processor the following indications are present: STM LED to indicate that the transmitter is not switched on. The LED is off, if the high voltage is switched on and no sector blanking is selected. MTI LED to indicate an air MTI video processing failure. The error report is generated if a failure is detected on one of the memory cards RXC-F-B-A/08 and A/11 or one of the canceller cards RXC-F-B-A/09 and A/12. The test data for these tests is injected by the MPX card RXC-F-B-A/07. LIN LED to indicate a surface LIN video processing failure. The error report is generated if a failure is detected on one of the linear processor cards RXC-F-B-A/19 and A/20. The test data for these tests is injected by the TIMING card RXC-F-B-A/22. LOG LED to indicate a surface LOG video processing failure. The error report is generated if a failure is detected on one of the logarithmic processor cards RXC-F-B-A/23 and A/24. The test data for these tests is injected by the TIMING card RXC-F-B-A/22. MTI~ LED to indicate an air LIN video processing failure. The error report is generated if a failure is detected on one of the linear air processor cards RXC-F-B-A/16 and A/17. The test data for these tests is injected by the MPX card RXC-F-B-A/07. 6.3 Test Connectors Behind the front panel of the video pr

ocessor the following test connectors are present: VIDEO MTI On this connector the MTI video for the display system can be measured. VIDEO LIN On this connector the linear MTI~ video for the display system can be measured. VIDEO On this connector the surface video for the display system can be LIN/LOG measured. The linear or logarithmic video is selected on the LCP or via the remote control panel (SURF LIN/LOG). SYNC On this connector the sync is present for the external equipment. If the above mentioned video signals are measured on an oscilloscope, the sync pulse must be used as trigger pulse.

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-2 4-7 9501 817 925XX CHP 004 01 009501 916 007XX CHP 001 00 006.4 Built-in Tests The video processor is provided with automatic video processor tests. For each sweep test data is injected into the air and surface video processing channels (see part 2A, chapter 6). If the test data is not processed correct, an error LED on the concerning card is lit and one of the LEDs MTI, LIN, LOG, MTI~ on the front panel of the video processor lights. For the LCP and the data handling a general RX error report is generated and on the LCP the LED CANC indicates the video processing failure. The following cards are tested by these built-in tests: MTI RXC-F-B-A/08, A/11 (memory cards) RXC-F-B-A/09, A/12 (canceller cards) LIN RXC-F-B-A/19, A/20 (linear processor cards) LOG RXC-F-B-A/23, A/24 (logarithmic processor cards) MTI~ RXC-F-B-A/16, A/17 (air linear processor cards) 7S W I T C H R A C K 7.1 Introduction The switch rack is provided with the following hardware test facilities: -i n d i c a t i o n s . 7.2 Indications On the front panel of the switch rack the following indications are present: 115 V 3 PH Three lamps to indicate that the 115 V, 50 Hz, 3-phase AVAIL ships supply voltage is present. 115 V 400 Hz This lamp indicates that the 115 V, 400 Hz, 1-phase ships AVAIL supply is present. 115 V 50/60 Hz Lamp to indicate that the supply voltage for the AVAIL anti-condensation heating is present. The l

amp does not indicate that the heaters are switched on or off. The units RXC-H-A/04 and B/01 in the switch rack are provided with LEDs. These are used for error reports of the stabilised low voltage supplies. Further see para 2.2 of this chapter.
 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-2 4-8 9501 817 925XX CHP 004 01 00 9501 916 007XX CHP 001 00 00

Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-2 5-1 9501 817 925XX CHP 005 00 009501 916 007XX CHP 001 00 00CHAPTER 5 Cooling Cabinet 1I N T R O D U C T I O N This chapter describes the hardware test facilities of the cooling cabinet which can be used for fault finding and testing. The test facilities of the cooling cabinet are given per rack or panel. The following panels are provided with test facilities: -r a d a r m o n i t o r ( U 1 ) , -w a v e g u i d e d r i e r ( U 2 ) , -c o o l i n g u n i t ( U 3 ) , -f u s e p a n e l . 2R A D A R M O N I T O R 2.1 Introduction The radar monitor is used to test the receiver (built-in test) and to monitor the transmitter output power. The front panel of the radar monitor is provided with a number of indications. 2.2 Indications The radar monitor is provided with the following indications: ALARM NOISE Lamp to indicate that the noise figure has exceeded FIGURE a preset value. When this lamp illuminates, the LED TEST SET on the LCP of the transmitter cabinet will illuminate after 30 seconds, and an RX fail message is sent to the data handling. ALARM OUTPUT Lamp to indicate that the transmitter output power POWER is below a preset value. When this lamp illuminates, the LED TEST SET on the LCP of the transmitter cabinet will be on and an RX fail message is sent to the data handling. Meter with switch With the metering switch in the NOISE FIGURE position, the reading must be less than 7. With
the metering switch in the OUTPUT POWER position, the reading must be more than 3600 W during transmission. POWER Lamp to indicate that the radar monitor is switched on.

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-2 5-2 9501 817 925XX CHP 005 00 00 9501 916 007XX CHP 001 00 002.3 Built-in Tests The radar monitor is used to test the receivers by measuring the noise figure. To measure the noise figure, every other sweep noise is injected into the receiver channel at the end of the listening time. The noise figure is calculated by comparing two consecutive sweeps (one with noise source on and one with noise source off). If the noise figure exceeds a preset value, the lamp ALARM NOISE FIGURE on the radar monitor illuminates as well as the LED TEST SET on the LCP of the transmitter cabinet. For the air receiver and the surface receiver separate noise sources are present. Because the radar monitor can measure only one noise figure at the same time, the receiver rack (RXC-B) of the receiver cabinet is provided with a selector switch NOISE TEST AIR/SURF. Listed below are the most important units which can cause a noise figure failure: Air receiver: -T X C - G - B / 0 1 , L N T A , -R X C - B - B / 0 1 , d o w n m i x e r R F , -R X C - B - F 5 , d o w n m i x e r I F , -R X C - B - C , S L S c i r c u i t , -R X C - B - D / 0 1 , P C a m p l i f i e r , -R X C - D - A / 0 1 , r e f e r e n c e g e n e r a t o r , -W G C - G C 1 6 , n o i s e s o u r c e . Surface receiver: -T X C - G - B / 0 2 , L N T A , -R X C - B - P / 0 1 , d o w n m i x e r R F , -R X C - B - F 7 , d o w n m i x e r I F , -R X C - D

- A / 0 1 , r e f e r e n c e g e n e r a t o r , -T X C - G - G C 2 3 , n o i s e s o u r c e . 3W A V E G U I D E D R I E R 3.1 Introduction The waveguide drier is provided with a number of indications. 3.2 Indications The following indications are present on the front panel of the waveguide drier: Moisture indicator The coulor of the indicator must be blue (= dry). Manometer The outlet pressure must be 1.45 - 1.95 bar. Air flow meter The flow must be 12 l/min, as calculated according to the formula on the front panel of the waveguide drier. OPERATION Lamp to indicate that the waveguide drier is switched on.

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-2 5-3 9501 817 925XX CHP 005 00 009501 916 007XX CHP 001 00 004C O O L I N G U N I T 4.1 Introduction The cooling unit is provided with a number of indications. 4.2 Indications Inside the cooling unit two thermometers are available. By means of the thermometer at the right hand top the temperature of the cooling water going to the transmitter cabinet can be read. By means of the thermometer at the left hand top the temperature of the returning cooling water from the transmitter cabinet can be read. Both thermometers must read a temperature of <50 ° C. At the right hand top, near the thermometer, a pressure meter is available, which indicates the water pressure to the transmitter cabinet. The meter must read 1.5 bar. 5F U S E P A N E L 5.1 Introduction The fuse panel is provided with the following hardware test facilities: -i n d i c a t i o n s , -t e s t s w i t c h . 5.2 Indications The fuse panel is provided with the following indications: Meter This meter is used to measure the resistance of the demineralised water, which is used for cooling of the transmitter cabinet. If the water conductivity is higher than the set level, the LEDs on the meter will illuminate and the error report WATER RES is sent to the LCP of the transmitter cabinet. The alarm level is set to 2.0 µSiemens. 440 V 50/60 Hz Three lamps to indicate that the 440 V, 50 Hz, 3 phase ships AVAILABLE supply voltage is pres

ent. 5.3 Test Switches The fuse panel is provided with the following test switch: TEST With this switch the operation of the pump in the cooling unit can be checked. If pressed, the pump is switched on, independent of the status of the radar system.

Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-3/1 1-1 9501 817 927XX CHP 001 01 009501 916 007XX CHP 001 00 00CHAPTER 1 General 1I N T R O D U C T I O N In this sub-section the software test facilities are described for the Antenna Control Unit (ACU). This sub-section is sub-divided as follows: Chapter 1 In this chapter the tools are explained for communication with the software. Chapter 2 In this chapter the test commands are given which are useful for maintenance. These test commands are given by means of the ANLED display with keys or by means of a TTW. Chapter 3 This chapter describes how the error reports are handled by the software and summarises the errors which can occur. Chapter 4 This chapter describes all on-line tests which are executed by the software. Also the possible defective components are mentioned if an on-line test is not completed successfully. Chapter 5 This chapter describes the off-line tests. 2I / O M E D I A 2.1 Introduction To give commands and to display status and error reports, the ANLED display with keys can be used or a TTW can be used. 2.2 ANLED Display The ANLED display with the four keys beneath it are used to give commands to the antenna control unit and are used for the display of status and error reports. Control via the ANLED is only possible in the local mode of operation. During remote control the display is switched off. If one of the keys is pressed, status and error reports can be display

ed. If during 30 minutes no key is pressed, the display is switched off. 2.3 TTW To give test commands and to obtain detailed reports, a PIOD must be connected to the PIOD-connector on the ACU rack (panel C).

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-3/1 1-2 9501 817 927XX CHP 001 01 00 9501 916 007XX CHP 001 00 00When a TTW must be connected, the following procedure must be followed: -o n t h e r e c e i v e r c a b i n e t p r e s s L O C A L ( p a n e l A ) , -s w i t c h t h e r e c e i v e r c a b i n e t o f f w i t h p u s h b u t t o n O F F , -c o n n e c t t h e T T W , -s w i t c h t h e r e c e i v e r c a b i n e t o n b y p r e s s i n g O F F a g a i n , -p r e s s L O C A L a g a i n i f t h e s y s t e m i s t o b e c o n t r o l l e d r e m o t e l y . Note: The baud rate for communication with a TTW is preset to 9600 baud. If the system is switched on, the TTW will print: Processor(s): 01 Successfully started OPERATOR TASKS ON HYPLA-MPU-: MPU : HYPLA HIGH: 15 LOW : 14 Any fault detected from this point will be printed automatically.

The report mode is selected with KEY 2 (concerning text on ANLED 3: ‘REPORT’). Above KEY 1 on ANLED 3 the selected report is displayed. Example: 1/3 STA This means that within the overlay 1, the report mode STA is in use. Fig. 2-2 shows the three overlays and the three report modes. So nine possibilities are present. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-3/1 2-3 9501 817 927XX CHP 002 01 009501 916 007XX CHP 001 00 002.2 Control Functions The functions of the keys for the available overlays are as follows (see also Fig. 2-1): Overlay 1, status report (1/3 STA) KEY 1 : Change of overlay (1, 2 or 3). KEY 2 : Select report mode (STA, FLT or PAR). KEY 3 : Select ANGL1, 2, 3 or 4. This is the stop angle for the bearing drive (resp. 0 °,9 0°,1 8 0 °,2 7 0 °). The antenna stops in the selected position ( ±20°). T h e s t o p a n g l e i s p r e s e t t o 0 ° (ANGL1). The bearing drive must be switched on and off twice to make the antenna stop at the correct position. This is necessary to determine the run out angle of the antenna after switching-off. KEY 4 : No function. Overlay 1, error report (1/3 FLT) KEY 1 : Change of overlay (1, 2 or 3). KEY 2 : Select report mode (STA, FLT or PAR). KEY 3 : Select previous errors in the error table (PREV). This is only applicable if more than two errors are detected. KEY 4 : Select next failure in the error table (NEXT). This is only applicable if more than two errors are detected. Overlay 1, parameter report (1/3 PAR) KEY 1 : Change of overlay (1, 2 or 3). KEY 2 : Select report mode (STA, FLT or PAR). KEY 3 : Select parameter A (PAR A). The parameters which can be selected, are summarised in para 2.5. KEY 4 : Select parameter B (PAR B). The parameters which can be selected, are summarised in para 2.5. Ove

rlay 2, status report (2/3 STA) The functions of the keys are the same as for overlay 1, status report (1/3 STA). Overlay 2, error report (2/3 FLT) KEY 1 : Change of overlay (1, 2 or 3). KEY 2 : Select report mode (STA, FLT or PAR). KEY 3 : Reset of all error reports (ERRESET). KEY 4 : Suppress or release error reports (BLANK/UBLANK). Errors which are blanked in this way, will not cause a local or remote error report. Only the reports are blanked; the protections remain operational. Overlay 2, parameter report (2/3 PAR) KEY 1 : Change of overlay (1, 2 or 3). KEY 2 : Select report mode (STA, FLT or PAR).

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-3/1 2-4 9501 817 927XX CHP 002 01 00 9501 916 007XX CHP 001 00 00KEY 3 : Select parameter C (PAR C). The parameters which can be selected, are summarised in para 2.5. KEY 4 : Select parameter D (PAR D). The parameters which can be selected, are summarised in para 2.5. Overlay 3, status report (3/3 STA) KEY 1 : Change of overlay (1, 2 or 3). KEY 2 Give commands (CMD1, CMD2, CMD3). KEY 3 The available commands are dependent of the platform status, as indicated in KEY 4 the table of Fig. 2-3. When less than three command are applicable (see Fig. 2-3), KEY 2 has its normal function; select report mode (STA, FLT or PAR). The meaning of the commands as mentioned in Fig. 2-3 is as follows: ANT ON Switch-on stabilisation and bearing drive. ANT SB Stabilisation and bearing drive stand-by. BD STOP Switch-off bearing drive. BD HIGH/LOW Switch-over from bearing drive speed. AUT-TST Switch-on of auto-test mode (see chapter 5, off-line tests). SB B-DRIVE STOP BD HIGH BD-LOW ANT SB MAN ALOFT REPORT - - AUTO HYPLA TEST REPORT Fig. 2-3 Commands via Keys

Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-3/1 2-6 9501 817 927XX CHP 002 01 00 9501 916 007XX CHP 001 00 003T T W 3.1 General The ACU is provided with a PIOD-connection. By means of a TTW tests can be started and error reports can be obtained. The TTW commands are designed for hardware and software development, fault finding and system testing. In this chapter only the TTW commands are given which are useful for fault finding and system testing. Two process numbers are available for communication with the TTW: -1 4 ( f o r l o w p r i o r i t y ) , -1 5 ( f o r h i g h p r i o r i t y ) . Process 15 is executed with the highest priority. The use of process 15 is not recommended, because operational processes can be disturbed. Communication with the TTW is started as follows: <CTRL>A 14<RETURN> The TTW will print: HYPLA> 14> After each command the communication process with the TTW is ended. This can be prevented by first typing the command: CM (continuous mode) If the communication with the TTW must be ended, the CM command must be given again. Then the TTW will print: Exit1 2 3Q-SHP Q-PLF Q-ERRShips roll angle Platform roll angle Stabilisation roll errorD D DPAR-C 1 2 3E-SHP E-PLF E-ERRShips pitch angle Platform pitch angle Stabilisation pitch errorD D DPAR-D *D = d e g r e e s D/S = degrees per second B = bar C = temperature in degrees CelsiusName Description Dimension* Parameter Fig. 2-4 System Parameters (continued)

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-3/1 2-7 9501 817 927XX CHP 002 01 009501 916 007XX CHP 001 00 00In para 3.2 the test commands are explained. In para 3.3 the tests are described, which can be executed by these commands. 3.2 TTW Commands 3.2.1 Introduction The TTW commands are available after typing: <CTRL>A 14<RETURN> or <CTRL>A 15<RETURN> (not recommended; see para 3.1). The SME commands have the following syntax: <COMMAND><SPACE>[<PARAMETERS>]<RETURN> The SME commands and their meaning are summarised in the table of Fig. 2-5. Command Meaning AB p Abort process p. AR [p1, p2] Alter routing so that data/command flow to p1 is sent to p2. BB, a, m [,s] Monitor shifted (s) contents of address a in mode m. BR Stop brush-recording. BT b Alter baud rate teletype line. * BL b Alter baud rate serial data link line. CM Toggle continuous mode. * CO [m] Give control-command m to HYPLA. * DO [a] Download test program at specified address. EP Print errors that have been registered. * ER n Set error report mode (n = 0, 1, 2, 3). * ET [p1 [, p2]] Examine status of processes p1 through p2. GO p Start process p. HE Help command. * IP m [,n] Display contents of parameter n of pool m. * LD n Log the next n scheduling actions. LG Enable logging of ships- and platform angles via the TTW-connection. * LK a [,n] Display n units of memory starting at address a. Fig. 2-5 SME Commands

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-3/1 2-8 9501 817 927XX CHP 002 01 00 9501 916 007XX CHP 001 00 00Most of the TTW commands are only meant for hardware and software development. The TTW commands useful for maintenance and fault finding are described in the next papagraphs. In Fig. 2-5 these commands are indicated by *. 3.2.2 Alter Baudrate Command (BT) By means of the BT command the baudrate value for TTW communication can be set (changed). Syntax BT XXXX<RETURN> (XXXX = decimal number) ParameterLP [m] Lock pool m, pool enabled to be written by TTW. * MR Release PVM-bus. MS, n, m [,s] Connect monitor-output of module n with rack-monitor. RT p Restart process p. RU Run test program. SA Stop all processes (except operator tasks). SE n Set event n. SL n [,s] Measure static cpu-load for n interals of s clock ticks. SP p Stop process p. TG n Display n TEE-loggings (TEE go). TP [m] Display lock-status of pool m. * TR [p] Exclude process p from TEE-logging (reset TEE-bit). TS [p] Include process p in TEE-logging (set TEE-bit). UP [m] Unlock pool m, pool disabled to be written by TTW. * VS Display SME/2 and application version numbers. Possibilities Meaning Default 75, 110, 134, Baudrate 9600 150, 300, 600, 1200, 1800, 2000, 2400, 4800, 9600, 19200Command Meaning Fig. 2-5 SME Commands (continued)

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-3/1 2-9 9501 817 927XX CHP 002 01 009501 916 007XX CHP 001 00 00Example BT 300<RETURN> The baudrate for TTW communication is now set at 300. Before any new commands can be entered, the TTW must also be set to 300 baud. 3.2.3 Continuous Mode Command (CM) The continuous mode command CM is used to continue or to end the communication with the TTW. Normally the communication is ended after each command. This is avoided by giving the CM command first. The communication can be ended later on by giving the CM command again (toggle). Syntax CM<RETURN> Parameter none Example <CTRL>A 14<RETURN> (HYPLA>14>)CM<RETURN> (HYPLA>14>)ER 1<RETURN> (HYPLA>14>)EP<RETURN> (HYPLA>14>)CM<RETURN> (Exit) The CM command is used twice here, first to continue the TTW control mode, after that to end this mode. The tell-back messages on the TTW are given between brackets. 3.2.4 Control Command (CO) By means of the CO command the antenna platform and bearing drive can be controlled by means of the TTW. Most control functions available with this command, can also be given via the KEYs with ANLED display. Syntax CO XX<RETURN> (XX = parameter)

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-3/1 2-10 9501 817 927XX CHP 002 01 00 9501 916 007XX CHP 001 00 00Parameters Example CO AT<RETURN> The antenna system is set into the auto-test mode. This test can be terminated with the command: CO AR<RETURN> 3.2.5 Error Print Command (EP) The EP command is used to print the errors, detected by the software, via the TTW. All errors that occurred after starting up or after a previous EP command are printed. Syntax EP<RETURN> Parameter None Example EP<RETURN> 3.2.6 Error Report Mode Command (ER) The ER command specifies in what form the error reporting via the TTW will take place. Syntax ER X<RETURN> (X = decimal number) Possibilities Meaning Default AO Antenna On Not applicable AS Antenna standby AT Auto Test AR Auto Test Ready BS Bearing-drive stop BL B-drive low (7.5 RPM) BH B-drive high (15 RPM)

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-3/1 2-11 9501 817 927XX CHP 002 01 009501 916 007XX CHP 001 00 00Parameters Example ER 1<RETURN> The errors are displayed on request, after command EP. 3.2.7 Logging Command (LG) This command enables the logging of ships- and platform angles via the TTW connection. The ships and platform angles (roll and pitch) are continuously transmitted to the TTW until a RETURN is received from the TTW. 3.2.8 Help Command (HE) The HE command is used to print all commands as summarised in para 3.2.1, via the TTW. Syntax HE<RETURN> Parameter None Example HE<RETURN> All TTW commands are printed on the TTW. Possibilities Meaning Default 0 - 3 1 = Errors are only displayed after an EP command. 2 = Errors are only displayed on the first occurrence (one shot mode). 3 = Errors are displayed every time they are detected. 0 = Only used after ’one shot’ mode (ER 2) has been established. The ’one shot’ mode is initiated again.2

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-3/1 2-12 9501 817 927XX CHP 002 01 00 9501 916 007XX CHP 001 00 003.2.9 Pool Control Commands (IP, LP, TP, UP) 3.2.9.1 Introduction Communication between the software modules is performed via so-called ’pools’. A pool is a memory location or several memory locations. A software module writes data into a ’pool’, which can be read by one or more software modules. Pool control commands are used for adjustment of the antenna system (see part 5). WARNING: Injudicious use of the pools can damage the system. 3.2.9.2 Inspect/Change Pool Command (IP) The contents of the pools can be displayed on the TTW by means of the IP command. The IP command is used in combination with the LP command to change the pools contents. If the pool is locked (LP), the contents can be changed. Syntax IP XXX [YYY]<RETURN> (XXX = pool name, YYY = parameter) Parameters Example IP HYD<RETURN> The contents of pool HYD is displayed on the TTW, and further the following prompt is displayed: IP> After this prompt a pool name can be typed, followed by <RETURN>, where after the pool contents is displayed. WARNING: Injudicious use of the pools can damage the system. 3.2.9.3 Lock Pool Command (LP) This command takes care that the pool contents only can be changed by means of the TTW (command IP) and ’locks’ this pool for the application software.Parameter Possibilities Meaning XXX See para 3.3 Pool name YYY See para 3.3 Paramete
r used to select a data group (only applicable for the PAR pool)

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-3/1 2-13 9501 817 927XX CHP 002 01 009501 916 007XX CHP 001 00 00Syntax LP XXX<RETURN> (XXX = pool name) Parameter Pool name. For the pool names to be used see para 3.3. Example LP HYD<RETURN> The HYD pool is locked now. To change the pool, see para 3.3. WARNING: Injudicious use of the pools can damage the system. 3.2.9.4 Test Pool Command (TP) By means of the test pool command (TP) the pool status (locked or unlocked) is displayed. When no pool name is typed in, the status of all pools is displayed. Syntax TP XXX<RETURN> (XXX = pool name) Parameter Pool name. For the pool names to be used see paragraph 3.3. Example TP HYD<RETURN> The following is diplayed on the TTW now: pool ’HYD’: unlocked or pool ’HYD’: locked It is possible to display the status of all the pools by typing: TP<RETURN>

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-3/1 2-14 9501 817 927XX CHP 002 01 00 9501 916 007XX CHP 001 00 003.2.9.5 Unlock Pool Command (UP) The unlock pool command (UP) ’unlocks’ the pool (locked by the LP commmand). The pool contents can not be changed anymore by means of the TTW command IP. The pools are controlled again by the software. When no pool name is typed in, all pools are ’unlocked’. Syntax UP XXX<RETURN> (XXX = pool name) Parameter Pool name. For the pool names to be used see paragraph 3.3. Example UP HYD<RETURN> The HYD pool is unlocked now for operational use by the software. 3.3 Tests 3.3.1 Introduction The following paragraphs contain descriptions of a number of test and control facilities which are possible with the commands as mentioned in para 3.2. The test facilities are realised by reading or writing in certain pools by using the TTW. The used pools are mentioned in the table below. The test facilities are detailed as follows: -p u m p p r e s s u r e c o n t r o l , p a r a 3 . 3 . 2 , -s e r v o c o n t r o l , p a r a 3 . 3 . 3 , -B - d r i v e c o n t r o l , p a r a 3 . 3 . 4 , -i n p u t a n d o u t p u t d i s c r e t e s , p a r a 3 . 3 . 5 .Name Meaning PAR Parameter pool PIC P-I Control pool SPA Servo Pre-Amplifier pool HYD Hydraulic Interface pool BDC Bearing Drive pool ODP Output Discretes pool IDP Input Discretes pool

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-3/1 2-15 9501 817 927XX CHP 002 01 009501 916 007XX CHP 001 00 003.3.2 Pump Pressure Control The pump pressure setpoint can be displayed and eventually changed via the TTW. This is performed by means of the HYD pool. This pool contains the control value sent to the hydraulic interface card, by the software. The pool contains one data word, PRSSETP (pressure setpoint). This word is classified as follows: S = Sign (two’s complement). MSB = 75 bar. X = don’t care The pump pressure output has a hardware offset of 135 bar. The contents of PRSSETP is displayed on the TTW hexadecimal. The relationship between the pressure to be set and the hexadecimal value is given for some values in the table below. The set pump pressure is displayed and changed as follows (for example the pump pressure is set at 100 bar). (HYPLA> 14>)CM<RETURN> (HYPLA> 14>)LP HYD<RETURN> (HYPLA> 14>)IP HYD<RETURN> (PRSSETP XXX:)E300<RETURN> (E300:)<RETURN>Set pressure (bar) Contents of PRSSETP (HEX) 240 5990 220 4880 200 3800 180 2800 160 1600 140 0400 135 0000 120 F400 100 E300 80 D100 60 C000 40 AF00S MSB LSB X15 14 04 03 00

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-3/1 2-16 9501 817 927XX CHP 002 01 00 9501 916 007XX CHP 001 00 00The pressure is set at 100 bar now. The normal software control is restored via command: UP HYD<RETURN> When the set pressure only has to be displayed, command LP has to be left out. 3.3.3 Servo Control Three pools are available to influence the servo control: -S P A - p o o l , -P A R - p o o l , -P I C - p o o l . WARNING: Injudicious use of the pools can damage the system. SPA-pool The SPA-pool contains the control values for the servo pre-amplifier cards (SPA-cards). The pool contains two data words: Qe and Eie. The words are classified as follows: S = Sign (two’s complement). 0111 1111 1111 XXXX = maximum value 1000 0000 0000 XXXX = minimum value X = don’t care The contents of the Qe and Eie are displayed on the TTW hexadecimal. The control values can be displayed and changed as follows (for example the control values are set at 0). (HYPLA> 14>)CM<RETURN> (HYPLA> 14>)LP SPA<RETURN> (HYPLA> 14>)IP SPA<RETURN> (QE XXXX:)0<RETURN> (0000:)<RETURN> (EIE XXXX:)0<RETURN> (0000:)<RETURN> The control values are set at 0 now. This setting is used to control the antenna stabilisation and is related to the rotation velocity of the platform. To do this, the brakes of the hydraulic cylinders have to be released. This is described in paragraph 3.3.5. The normal software control is restored via command: UP SPA<RETURN>S MSB LSB X15 14

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-3/1 2-17 9501 817 927XX CHP 002 01 009501 916 007XX CHP 001 00 00When the control values only have to be displayed, command LP has to be left out. PAR-pool The PAR-pool contains parameters for servo control and pump pressure control. The parameters are subdivided into six groups: -f i l t e r p a r a m e t e r s ( F I L ) , -s w i t c h p a r a m e t e r s ( S W I ) , -s i m u l a t i o n p a r a m e t e r s ( S I M ) , -r e g i s t r a t i o n p a r a m e t e r s ( N S D ) , -p u m p p r e s s u r e c o n t r o l p a r a m e t e r s ( P P C ) , -l o g g i n g p a r a m e t e r s ( L O G P A R ) . A parameter group can be displayed on the TTW. Example IP PAR SWI<RETURN> All switch parameters are printed. Only the switch parameters (SWI), simulation parameters (SIM) and registration parameters (NSD) are important for testing and maintenance. -S w i t c h p a r a m e t e r s The Q- and E- servo channels contain three software switches (SW1-SW3) each. The switches are shown in Fig. 2-6. The switch positions are coded a follows: •S W 1 : 0 = s h i p s d a t a o n i n p u t ( Q e a n d E i e , o p e r a t i o n a l p o s i t i o n ) 1=input signal is zero 2=simulation data on input (Qsim and Eisim) •S W 2 - S W 3 : 0 = o p e r a t i o n a l p o s i t i o n 1=input signal is zero

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-3/1 2-18 9501 817 927XX CHP 002 01 00 9501 916 007XX CHP 001 00 00-S i m u l a t i o n p a r a m e t e r s As i m u l a t i o nt e s tc a nb es e tb yt h es i m u l a t i o np a r a m e t e r s .T h es i m u l a t i o ni ss e ts e p a r a t e l yf o r the Qe- and Eie- channel. For each channel the following four words have to be defined. •F M O ( s i m u l a t i o n m o d e ) : 0 = n o s i m u l a t i o n , 1=sine simulation, 2=step simulation, 3=triangle simulation. •F F R ( f r e q u e n c y o f s i m u l a t i o n m o v e m e n t i n H z ; d e c i m a l v a l u e ) . •F A M ( a m p l i t u d e o f s i m u l a t i o n m o v e m e n t i n r a d ; d e c i m a l v a l u e ) . •F O F ( o f f - s e t o f s i m u l a t i o n m o v e m e n t i n r a d ; d e c i m a l v a l u e ) . -R e g i s t r a t i o n p a r a m e t e r s The strength of the control error signal (REST ERRORS in Fig. 2-6) on the REGISTRATION test points on the front panel of the ACU rack, can be set by the registration (shift) parameters. To do this the NSD (number of shifts for registration channels) word has to be filled in. A decimal value is filled in which indicates how many bits the binary signal value has to be shifted to the left. The next example shows how to start a simulation test for the Qe channel by using the PAR-pool and the PIC-pool. The PIC-pool is described at the end of this paragraph. Example (HYPLA> 14>
)CM<RETURN> (HYPLA> 14>)LP PAR<RETURN> (HYPLA> 14>)LP PIC<RETURN> (HYPLA> 14>)IP PIC CTRL<RETURN> (CTRL:)2 <RETURN><RETURN> (servo control on) Fig. 2-6 Servo Algorithm with Software Switches

This word is defined as follows: 0 = servo control off 1 = servo control zero 2 = servo co

ntrol on (operational) 3 = servo control test (auto test mode) The PIC-pool is used in the example above. 3.3.4 B-Drive Control BDC-pool De BDC-pool contains the control word (CTRL) for the bearing drive control. This word is defined as follows: 0 = B-drive off (stop without zero position) 1 = B-drive low 2 = B-drive high 3 = B-drive stop (stop with zero position)

The table in Fig. 2-8 shows the meaning of the output discretes bits. WARNING: Injudicious use of the pools can damage the system. In principle it is possible to change the output discretes pools with the LP and IP commands. However be extremely careful doing this, to avoid damage to the antenna system, specially in case of switching from high speed to low speed. During normal operation the software switches low speed on when the antenna speed has become low enough. This protection is of course not present in case of TTW control. The brakes of the hydraulic cylinders may be released by changing this ODP-pool via the TTW. This can be done for the following situations: -t o p e r f o r m c e r t a i n t e s t s n e c e s s a r y f o r f a u l t f i n d i n g , -t o c o n t r o l t h e p l a t f o r m w i t h t h e j o y s t i c k ( t o b e c o n n e c t e d o n t h e f r o n t p a n e l o f t h e A C U ) .Word Bitno. Type on the TTW: (HYPLA> 14>)LP ODP<RETURN> (HYPLA> 14>)IP ODP<RETURN> The contents of word OD1 is displayed on the TTW as a hexadecimal number: OD1 XXXX: When the second digit is changed into a 3, the brakes are released. A fault report can be printed on the TTW and can be displayed on the ANLED display as follows: MPU RAM ERROR 2.4 DUART Tests The DUART on the RCI-2 card (RXC-C-A-A/30) is used for communication with the TTW. These serial data link is checked by the following tests: -f r a m i n g t e s t ( w o r d l e n g t h a n d s t a r t a n d s t o p b i t s ) , -o v e r r u n t e s t ( i n p u t b u f f e r f u l l ) , -p a r i t y c h e c k . Framing Test The framing test checks the word length, start bit and stop bit of a data transport from the TTW. If an error is detected the following message is printed on the TTW: DEVICE error: TTW framing error Ov

errun Test An overrun is present if the TTW transmits more characters than the MPU can read within a time window. In this case the TTW will print: DEVICE error: TTW overrun error Parity Check Each data word from the TTW is provided with a parity bit. The parity is checked by the software. If a parity error is detected, the following message is printed on the TTW: DEVICE error: TTW parity error If one of these faults is present, this is probably caused by a defective RCI-2 card (RXC-C-A-A/30) or by a defect of the TTW.

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-3/1 4-3 9501 817 927XX CHP 004 00 009501 817 171XX CHP 003 00 002.5 Rack Monitor Test The rack monitor card (PRC-C-A-A/31) is functionally tested by the rack monitor test. The test consists of two parts: -R A M t e s t , -c a t c h c i r c u i t t e s t . Each test is controlled by the software received via the C-bus. Data and clock pulses are sent to the rack monitor via the PVM-bus. Data is stored in the rack monitor RAM. The data in the RAM is checked by the software via the C-bus. The test is executed at a low priority. The data in the RAM can be made visable on an oscilloscope, via the connectors MON and TRIG on the front panel of the ACU. On the oscilloscope a saw-tooth voltage must be present. In case of a failure, one or more of the following messages will be printed on the TTW: DEVICE error: RM RAM error DEVICE error: RM CATCH error If one of these faults occurs, this is probably caused by a defective rack monitor card (RXC-C-A-A/31), the RCI-2 card (A/30) or the LIU INT card (A/27). 3H A R D W A R E T E S T S O F A N T E N N A S Y S T E M 3.1 Introduction To check the operation of the antenna system, the following on-line tests are carried out: -h y d r a u l i c c o n t r o l t e s t ( p a r a 3 . 2 ) , -s y n c h r o t e s t s ( p a r a 3 . 3 ) , -L I U i n t e r f a c e t e s t ( p a r a 3 . 4 ) , -I / O d i s c r e t e s t e s t ( p a r a 3 . 5 ) , -f u s e t e s t ( p a r

a 3 . 6 ) , -s t a b i l i s a t i o n t e s t ( p a r a 3 . 7 ) , -B - d r i v e c o n t r o l t e s t s ( p a r a 3 . 8 ) , -H P U c o n t r o l t e s t s ( p a r a 3 . 9 ) , -p l a t f o r m c o n t r o l t e s t s ( p a r a 3 . 1 0 ) . 3.2 Hydraulic Control Test The hydaulic control card HYDR CONTR (RXC-C-A-A/17) is provided with an error detection circuit. If the pump pressure control voltage remains too high (pressure above 150 bar) for at least 40 seconds, a hydraulic pressure control failure is reported to the MPU. On the ANLED display and the TTW the following error report can be displayed: EL. CIRC HYDR CONTR FAILS Most of the time, the failure source will be the HYDR CONTR card RXC-C-A-A/17 or the HPU.

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-3/1 4-4 9501 817 927XX CHP 004 00 00 9501 817 171XX CHP 003 00 003.3 Synchro Tests The input signals for the S/D converters in the ACU are checked by the software at the following points: -r e f e r e n c e v o l t a g e , -c h a n g e o f t h e s y n c h r o v a l u e . If a failure is detected this is reported via the ANLED display and the TTW. Example: SYNCHRO Q-PLF CHANGE TOO LARGE In the table of Fig. 4-1 all synchro error reports with associated SD-converter are given. Af a i l u r ec a nb ec a u s e db yad e f e c to nt h ec a r do rb yt h es o u r c ew h i c hs u p p l i e st h er e l a t e ds y n c h r oo r reference voltage. Besides the synchro tests, the MPU also checks the status reports from the RTU, which indicate if the ships synchro signals are available. If they are not available, the following error report can be displayed on the ANLED and the TTW: SYNCHRO RTU FAILS 3.4 LIU Interface Test After a data transport between MPU and LIU INT card RXC-C-A-A/27, the MPU receives a status word. This word contains an acknowledge bit to indicate that the MPU-data is succesfully placed on the IU-bus. Furthermore the IU-bus is checked by means of a loop test. If the MPU does not receive an acknowledge or if the loop test fails, the following error report is generated for the ANLED display and the TTW: EL.CIRC LIU INTERF. FAILS If this error report is present, the failure source is mo

stly the LIU INT card (RXC-C-A-A/27), but can also be one of the other cards connected to the IU-bus.Failure report Card position Cause E-PLF CHANGE TOO LARGE Q-PLF CHANGE TOO LARGE E-SHP CHANGE TOO LARGE Q-SHP CHANGE TOO LARGE E-PLF REF FAILS Q-PLF REF FAILS E-SHP FINE REF FAILS Q-SHP FINE REF FAILS E-SHP COARSE REF FAILS Q-SHP COARSE REF FAILSRXC-C-A-A/14 RXC-C-A-A/14 RXC-C-A-A/12 RXC-C-A-A/11 RXC-C-A-A/14 RXC-C-A-A/14 RXC-C-A-A/12 RXC-C-A-A/11 RXC-C-A-A/12 RXC-C-A-A/11Change too large Reference voltage too low Fig. 4-1 Synchro Error Reports

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-3/1 4-5 9501 817 927XX CHP 004 00 009501 817 171XX CHP 003 00 003.5 I/O Discretes Test The I/O DISCR cards (RXC-C-A-A/25 and A/26) are tested via a loop test on the MSB of the data word. If this loop test fails, the following error report is generated for the ANLED display and the TTW: EL. CIRC I/O DISCR 1(2) FAILS The failure source is mostly the concerning I/O DISCR card RXC-C-A-A/25 (I/O DISCR 1), RXC-C-A-A/26 (I/O DISCR 2) or RXC-C-A-A/27 (LIU INT). 3.6 Fuse Test If one of the automatic fuses on the ACU is tripped or switched off, a message is sent to the software via an input discrete. This is reported to the ANLED display and the TTW as follows: EL. CIRC FUSE FAILS 3.7 Stabilisation Test The software continuously checks the position error of the platform, for Qe and Eie. If this error becomes more than 0.5 °the following error report are generated for the ANLED display and the TTW (dependent on the error in degrees): PLATF STAB RESTERRORS > 0.5 D PLATF STAB RESTERRORS > 0.7 D PLATF STAB RESTERRORS > 1.0 D The failure source can be one of the SPA cards RXC-C-A-A/21 and A/22, the HYDR INTF card RXC-C-A-A/20 or another failure in the servo loop, such as a defective servo valve, hydraulic actuator etc. 3.8 B-Drive Control Tests For the B-drive control, the software checks the following: -B - d r i v e b r a k e , -r o t a t i o n a l s p e e d , -o i l p r e s s u r e f o r B - d r i v

e . The B-drive brake status (released or activated) is checked via the input discretes. If the brake is not released the following report is generated for the ANLED display and the TTW: B-DRIVE BRAKE FAILS

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-3/1 4-6 9501 817 927XX CHP 004 00 00 9501 817 171XX CHP 003 00 00By means of the bearing data the rotational speed of the antenna is checked. If the speed exceeds a deviation of 10% of the selected RPM, the following error report is generated for the ANLED display and the TTW: B-DRIVE ROTATION FAILS Via a pressure sensor and an input discrete the software checks if the oil pressure is high enough. If the oil pressure is too low, the following error report is generated for the ANLED display and the TTW: B-DRIVE OIL PRESSURE TOO LOW The failure source for these three error reports can be one of the relay cards RXC-D-A-A/23 or A/24 or the I/O discretes card RXC-C-A-A/26, the HPU or the bearing drive motor M1 or the lubrication oil pump M2 in the antenna. 3.9 HPU Control Tests The software can receive a number of error reports from the HPU, via input discretes. These reports are displayed on the ANLED display and TTW as follows: HPU FATAL ERROR HPU FAILURE HPU LOCAL (status report) HPU OIL PRESSURE LOW The meaning of these reports is clear. When one of these reports occurs the HPU manual has to be consulted. Only in case of the HPU FAILURE report, the antenna stabilisation will still be available. In case of one of the three other HPU reports, stabilisation is not possible. The source of these failures, except for the HPU oil pressure too low failure, can be the HPU, relay card (RXC-C-A-A/24

) or I/O DISCR card (RXC-C-A-A/25). In case of a HPU oil pressure too low failure, the failure source can be the HPU or the hydraulic control card (RXC-C-A-A/17). 3.10 Platform Control Tests The software receives the following reports from the platform: -t e m p e r a t u r e ( a n a l o g u e ) , b y m e a n s o f t e m p e r a t u r e t r a n s d u c e r s , -o i l p r e s s u r e , f r o m a p r e s s u r e s w i t c h , -m a n u a l m o d e ; t h i s i s a n i n d i c a t i o n t h a t t h e N O R M A L / P U M P O F F s w i t c h i s i n t h e P U M P O F F position. Dependent on these reports, the following messages are displayed on the ANLED display and TTW:

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-3/2 1-1 9501 817 928XX CHP 001 00 009501 817 172XX CHP 001 00 00CHAPTER 1 General 1I N T R O D U C T I O N In this sub-section the software test facilities for the Frequency Control and Timing Unit (FCTU) are described. This sub-section is divided into the following chapters: Chapter 1 Details the layout of the sub-section and outlines the actions necessary in order to connect a TTW to the FCTU. Chapter 2 Describes all test commands available for maintenance purposes. These test commands are input by means of the TTW. Chapter 3 Details how fault reports are handled by the software and provides a summary of all available fault indications. Chapter 4 Gives a description of all on-line tests executed by the software. This chapter also supplies possible fault causes for on-line tests which are not successful. 2I / O M E D I U M In order to give test commands to the software, or to receive detailed reports from the software, a TTW must be connected to the relevant connector on the FCTU rack (rack D, lower left hand side). Prior to connecting the TTW the rack supply must be turned off. The subsequent connection actions are as follows: -p l a c e t h e r e c e i v e r c a b i n e t t o L O C A L b y m e a n s o f t h e s w i t c h L O C A L a t t h e s u p p l y r a c k , -s w i t c h t h e r e c e i v e r c a b i n e t o f f v i a t h e O F F s w i t c h , -c o n n e c t t h e T T W , -s w i t

c h t h e r e c e i v e r c a b i n e t o n b y p r e s s i n g t h e O F F s w i t c h a g a i n , -P r e s s t h e s w i t c h L O C A L a g a i n i f t h e s y s t e m i s t o b e c o n t r o l l e d r e m o t e l y . Note: The baud rate for communication with a TTW is preset to 300 baud. The Bits/character is 7. Parity is ON. Parity sense is EVEN. After system switch on the following report will be printed at the TTW: Processor(s): 1 Successfully started OPERATOR TASKS ON FCTU-MPU: MPU : FCTU 5 HIGH : 15

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Refer to Chapter 2 for information relevant to starting TTW communications in order to give test commands.

All user commands and meanings are summarized in the following table. (cVe) on/off 0≤ INT ≤ 1 PO INT<RETURN> PCN only 0≤ PO ≤ 1 not used VE INT<RETURN> Ve 10-2m/s 0≤ INT ≤2000 KE INT<RETURN> Ke degrees 0≤ INT ≤ 359 EI INT<RETURN> Eie degrees -89≤ INT ≤ 89 QE INT<RETURN> Qe degrees -89≤ INT ≤ 89 VT INT<RETURN> Vet 10-2m/s 0≤ INT ≤1500 KT INT<RETURN> Ket degrees 0 ≤ INT ≤ 359 BR INT<RETURN> Target bearing degrees -11)≤ INT ≤ 359 RA INT<RETURN> Target range 20 meters 10 ≤ INT ≤ 5000

The use of each command is outlined in the following paragraphs. 2.2 PRT Mode Command (PM) This command chooses between either short pulse or long pulse mode. Syntax PM X<RETURN> (X is a decimal number) Parameter Example PM 0<RETURN> The short pulse mode is selected. 2.3 PRT Value Command (PT) By means of this command the PRT is set to a fixed value. Prior to using this command the PRT mode must be determined by the PM command. Syntax PT XXX<RETURN> (XXX is a decimal number)TV INT<RETURN> Target velocity m/s -1500 ≤ INT ≤ 1500 MR INT<RETURN> Maximum range 20 meters 10 ≤ INT ≤ 5000 SS<RETURN> Start/Stop simulation HE<RETURN> Help EN INT<RETURN> End communication 0 ≤ INT ≤ 1 0 = MPU RESET 1 = stop communication Possible values Meaning Preset value 0 - 1 0 = Short pulse 1 = Long pulse--Command Parameter/meaning Unit Min/max value

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-3/2 2-4 9501 817 928XX CHP 002 00 00 9501 817 172XX CHP 001 00 00Parameter Example PM 0<RETURN> PT 1000<RETURN> The PRT is set to 1000 µs. 2.4 Frequency Mode Command (FM) By using this command the user can select between fixed frequency (FF), pseudo frequency agility (PSFA) and frequency agility (FA). Syntax FM X<RETURN> (X is a decimal number) Parameter Example FM 0<RETURN> The fixed frequency mode is chosen (default frequency for FM 0 is frequency 32). 2.5 Select Frequency Command (FR) This command selects the frequency number of the synthesizer. When this command is used the frequency mode is automatically set to fixed frequency. All synthesizer frequencies can be chosen with this command, including those frequencies outside of the ships working set. Syntax FR XX<RETURN> (XX is a decimal number)Possible values Meaning Preset value 975 - 1070 1900 - 2130PRT in µs during short pulse mode PRT in µs during long pulse mode-- -- Possible values Meaning Preset value 0 - 2 0 = FF 1 = PSFA 2 = FA--

Use of this command causes the settings input from either, the data handling system, or the local control panel to become invalid. Syntax SL X<RETURN> for STC ANGEL, (X is a decimal number) SA X<RETURN> for STC AIR, (Y is a decimal number) SU X<RETURN> for STC SURF. (Z is a decimal number) Parameter Example SA 2<RETURN> The STC AIR I mode is chosen. 2.7 MTI-Correction Command (MT) This command can switch the MTI-correction (cVe circuit for correction own speed) on and off. Use of this command will override the MTI-correction command from the data handling system, only for tidal speed and tidal course.Possible values Meaning Preset value 4 - 59 Synthesizer frequency number -- -- Possible values Meaning Preset value SL: 0 - 1 0 = STC ANGEL OFF 1 = STC ANGEL ON-- -- SA: 1 - 2 1 = STC AIR I OFF 2 = STC AIR I ON-- SU: 1 - 2 1 = STC SURF I ON 2 = STC SURF II ON--

Syntax VE XXXX<RETURN> (XXXX is a decimal number) Parameter Example VE 250<RETURN> The own speed is set to 2.5 m/s. 2.9 Own Course Command (KE) The own course is set by means of this command. Syntax KE XXX<RETURN> (XXX is a decimal number)Possible values Meaning Preset value 0 - 1 0 = OFF 1 = ON-- Possible values Meaning Preset value 0 - 2000 VE = XXX.10-2m/s --

Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-3/2 2-7 9501 817 928XX CHP 002 00 009501 817 172XX CHP 001 00 00Parameter Example KE 120<RETURN> The own course is set to 120 . 2.10 Pitch Command (EI) This command sets a fixed pitch value in place of the ships pitch value. Syntax EI SXX<RETURN> (S = + or - sign, XX is a decimal number) Parameter Example EI -12<RETURN> The pitch is set to the fixed value -12 . 2.11 Roll Command (QE) This command sets a fixed roll value in place of the ships roll value. Syntax QE SXX<RETURN> (S = + or - sign, XX is a decimal number) Parameter Example QE -12<RETURN>Possible values Meaning Preset value 0 - 359 Course in degrees -- Possible values Meaning Preset value -89 - +89 Pitch in degrees -- Possible values Meaning Preset value -89 - +89 Roll in degrees --

The value of the tidal speed received from the data handling system is then ignored. Syntax VT XXXX<RETURN> (XXXX is a decimal number) Parameter Example VT 500<RETURN> The tidal speed is set to 5 m/s. 2.13 Tidal Course Command (KT) With this command the tidal course is set. The value of the tidal course received from the data handling system is then ignored. Syntax KT XXX<RETURN> (XXX is a decimal number) Parameter Example KT 120<RETURN> The tidal course is set to 120 °.Possible values Meaning Preset value 0 - 1500 VT = XXXX.10-2m/s -- Possible values Meaning Preset value 0 - 359 Tidal course in degrees --

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-3/2 2-9 9501 817 928XX CHP 002 00 009501 817 172XX CHP 001 00 002.14 Simulated Target Bearing Command (BR) This command allows the input of a simulated target bearing. The distance and speed of the simulated target can be altered with the RA and TV commands (see following paragraphs). If the value -1 is submitted the simulated target is injected into all sweeps. This will cause a constant ring to be displayed. Simulation is started and stopped by using the SS command. Syntax BR SXXX<RETURN> (S = + or - sign, XXX is a decimal number) Parameter Examples BR -1<RETURN> TV 0<RETURN> SS<RETURN> A constant ring will be displayed. The description for the command TV is contained in paragraph 2.16. BR 15<RETURN> SS<RETURN> A simulated target will be displayed with a bearing of 15 °. Remark: In order to display test targets a connection between the FCTU and the receiver rack must be made. This connection is described in section 2, chapter 4, paragraph 3.3 of this handbook part. 2.15 Simulated Target Distance Command (RA) This command allows the input of a simulated target (or ring) distance. Due to hardware limits a simulated target will not be displayed if the distance is less than 12 km. Syntax RA XXXX<RETURN> (XXXX is a decimal number)Possible values Meaning Preset value 0 - 359 -1Bearing of the simulated target in degrees Ring simulation0

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-3/2 2-10 9501 817 928XX CHP 002 00 00 9501 817 172XX CHP 001 00 00Parameter Example RA 1200<RETURN> This distance of the simulated target (or ring) is 24000m. 2.16 Simulated Target Speed Command (TV) This command allows the input of a simulated targets speed. If the input speed value is positive, the simulated target will move in the direction from the start distance (set by the RA command), to the maximum distance (input by the MR command). If the speed value is negative, the simulated target will travel towards the centre of the display. In the case of ring simulation (see paragraph 2.14) the TV command will have the following result: -i f t h e s p e e d v a l u e i s 0 , a r i n g i s d i s p l a y e d , -i f t h e s p e e d i s o t h e r t h a n 0 , a s p i r a l i s d i s p l a y e d . Syntax TV SXXXX<RETURN> (S = + or - sign, XXXX is a decimal number) Parameter Example TV -150<RETURN> The speed of the simulated target is set to -150 m/s. 2.17 Maximum Distance of a Simulated Target Command (MR) With the MR (Maximum Range) command the maximum distance of simulated targets is set. Syntax MR XXXX<RETURN> (XXXX is a decimal number)Possible values Meaning Preset value 10 - 5000 Distance = XXXX.20 m 1000 Possible values Meaning Preset value -1500 - +1500 Target speed in m/s 300

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-3/2 2-11 9501 817 928XX CHP 002 00 009501 817 172XX CHP 001 00 00Parameter Example MR 150<RETURN> The maximum distance is set to 3000 m. 2.18 Start/Stop Simulation Command (SS) This command starts and stops target simulation. Simulation is not possible in the frequency agility mode and use of this command will display the following message on the TTW: NO SIMULATION IN MODE FA The same happens if the frequency agility mode is selected during simulation. Syntax SS<RETURN> Parameter None Example SS<RETURN> If in simulation, simulation is stopped. If not in simulation, simulation is started. 2.19 Help Command (HE) This command displays all user commands summarized in paragraph 2.1 at the TTW. Syntax HE<RETURN> Parameter NonePossible values Meaning Preset value 10 - 5000 Maximum distance = XXXX.20m 5000

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-3/2 2-12 9501 817 928XX CHP 002 00 00 9501 817 172XX CHP 001 00 00Example HE<RETURN> All user commands are printed at the TTW. 2.20 End Communications Command (EN) This command terminates the communications connection between the user command process and the TTW. The parameter given with this command will cause either a microprocessor reset, or the all parameter values input during the communication session to remain valid. Syntax EN X<RETURN> (X is a decimal number) Parameter Example EN 1<RETURN> Communications with the TTW and the user command process are stopped. All parameter values remain valid, i.e. when a target simulation has been started, simulation remains active. 3S M E C O M M A N D S 3.1 Introduction The SME commands become available after the following input: <CTRL>A 16<RETURN> or <CTRL>A 15<RETURN> (not recommended, see para 1) The commands have the following syntax: <COMMAND><SPACE><PARAMETER><RETURN>Possible values Meaning Preset value 0 - 1 0 = Reset microprocessor 1 = Stop communications--

Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-3/2 2-14 9501 817 928XX CHP 002 00 00 9501 817 172XX CHP 001 00 003.2 Alter Baud Rate Command (BT) This command allows the TTW communications rate to be given different values. Syntax BT XXXX<RETURN> (XXXX is a decimal value) Parameter Example BT 9600<RETURN> The communication rate for the TTW is set to 9600 baud. 3.3 Continuous Mode Command (CM) In normal usage of the TTW the SME-operator mode is ended after each command is given. The CM command is a toggle command used to either, hold TTW communications in the SME-operator mode, or to release the TTW from the SME-operator mode. Syntax CM <RETURN> Parameter None Example <CTRL>A 16<RETURN> FCTU> 16>CM<RETURN> FCTU> 16>ER 1<RETURN> FCTU> 16>EP<RETURN> FCTU> 16>CM<RETURN> (Exit) The CM command is used twice, initially to continue in the SME-operator mode and then to end the SME-operator mode. The tell-back messages on the TTW are given between brackets.Possible values Meaning Preset value 75, 110, 134, 150, 300, 600, 1200, 1800, 2000, 2400, 9600, 19200Baud rate 300

 Hollandse Signaalapparaten B.V. Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-3/2 2-15 9501 817 928XX CHP 002 00 009501 817 172XX CHP 001 00 003.4 Error Print Command (EP) This command is used to print all software detected faults at the TTW. Since the last EP command all detected faults are printed. Syntax EP<RETURN> Parameter None Example EP<RETURN> 3.5 Error Report Mode Command (ER) The ER command is used to set the manner of fault reporting at the TTW. Syntax ER X<RETURN> (X is a decimal number) Parameter Example ER 1<RETURN> Faults are only printed after the receipt of an EP command.Possible values Meaning Preset value 0 - 3 1 : Faults are only printed after an EP command. 2 : Faults are only printed after the first time of detection (one shot mode). 3 : Every fault is printed each time it is detected. 0 : Only to be used with the one shot mode. The one shot mode is restarted.2

Syntax HE<RETURN> Parameter None Example HE<RETURN> All SME commands are printed at the TTW.

Subject to restrictive legend on title pageLW08 - 6B(3)-3/2 4-2 9501 817 928XX CHP 004 00 00 9501 817 172XX CHP 003 00 002.3 RAM Test This tests the RAM resident on the MPU card, RXC-D-E-A/30. The time between two successive sync pulses is measured (approximately 4 ms, dependent upon PRF mode). If the time between two successive sync pulses does not change the following fault report is printed at the TTW: FCTU failure: System time fails This fault report indicates a fault with the XMTR-CTRL card (RXC-D-E-A/25). 3.4 C-Bus Loop Test The MPU executes a loop test on the C-bus by placing a test word on the bus. ailure: Looptest RELDA-INT-B fails The first report is relevant to RXC-D-E-A/10, the second to A/15.

Fig.1.A4S:PK/PDsimulator work flowchart Sandeep Sanga et. al [5] worked on a computer simulation to predict drug pharmacokinetics and effect in vascularized tumors .This paper explores the pharmacokinetics and effects of cisplatin and doxorubicin in vascularized tumors through 2D computer simulations . The study supports the idea that simulation -based modeling is vital in understanding the pharmacological behavior , as stated in the work of Sruthi V.B. [6] who demonstrated that simulation -based training also significantly improves applied medical skillsets like CPR .The authors take vascular and morphological heterogeneity into account and also cellular and lesion -level PK determinants like cell density P-glycoprotein (Pgp) efflux . A multi - compartmental PK/ PD model was constructed from experimental data and a 2-hour bolus administration and sub

secuently a 18-hour drug washout was simulated . The authors observed that vascular architecture , nutrient gradients , and cellular density played important roles in tumor penetration . The model incorporates differential equations to simulate drug transport , cellular uptake , and tumor response . The tumor microenvironment is modelled using steady - state diffusion equations which determine distribution of nutrients and oxygen . PD is model ed using a Hill-type function , linking drug exposure to cell inhibition . IV.PRECISE DOSE DESIGN The goal istodevelop aninteractive software that could simulate real-world medical emergency situations andenable practitioners tocalibrate drug dosages based upon several patient -specific parameters . Thesoftwareisprimarily divided intotwoparts :Theback -end model thatperforms thedrug dosage prediction andinterfac e, which isaimed tobefully interactive inorder togive theuser a realistic experience ofperforming under thestress during a medical emergency . PreciseDose isbuilt onPython 3.10.The libraries used inthesoftware aregiveninTable1. Table1.Librariesusedandtheirpurpose A.System Architecture Thearchitecture ofPreciseDose isstructured insuch away thatintegration between thesimulation environment ,prediction model ,and the user interface is smooth during communication between thementioned .Thesystem isdivided into sub-modules : • Patients ’JSON filerepository • Drugs ’JSON filerepository • ONNX dosage prediction model • Custom LinkedList andGraph data-structures • RealtimeSTT (Speech -To-Text)using PyTorch • Llama 3.2text-based feature extraction • Tkinter Interface 1) Flat-filedata repositories :JSON filesareflexible interms ofstructure and versatility .Patients ’JSON files consist information likedefault parameters ,vitals ,history ,etc.while drugs ’files JSON contain drug specific parameters likenormal doselevels ,bioavailability ,clearance rateandabsorption time. 2) ONNX Integration :Python hasexcellent support forOpen Neural Network Exchange (ON

NX )through ORT (ONNX RunTime ).This allows forquick loading andinfer ence of models stored inthe.onnx format directly .One more reason why wedecided tointegrate ONNX isdue toitscross - framework compatibility ,allowing ustoinitially develop and train themodelusing MATLAB andthen deploy itusing Python .3)Speech -To-Text using PyTorch :RealtimeSTT listens to themicrophone andtranscribes voice intotext.Itisbased upon 2dependency models :aV AD (V oice Activity Detection )filter andaSpeech Recognition Model . •SileroV AD foraccurate verification ofvoice activity . •Faster Whisper forGPU -accelerated transcrip tion. 4)Text feature extraction using Llama 3.2:Wehave in- corporated Llama 3.2,alightweight (3Bparameter )Large Language Model inorder toserve basic language tasks such astoextract keypatient parameters from atranscript ,compare user’sprocedure with theexpected and provid e feedback. 5)Tkinter Interface :When thesoftware isrun,Tkinter is called forthecreation ofafull-screen window (1920x1080 resolution bydefault ). B.Hierarchical filesystem PreciseDose makes useofWindows ’hierarchical filesystem thatuses directories toorganize files intoatreestructure .Code andcontent aremanaged indifferent dedicated sub-directories andevery individual filepath istracked andeasily traceable .
